Chief Complaint: Acute Renal Failure
   24 Hour Events:
   History obtained from Medical records, transferring team
   Allergies:
   History obtained from Medical records, transferring teamOxycodone
   Nausea/Vomiting
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) - [**2138-9-25**] 05:55 AM
   Vancomycin - [**2138-9-25**] 08:00 AM
   Infusions:
   Norepinephrine - 0.08 mcg/Kg/min
   Calcium Gluconate (CRRT) - 1 grams/hour
   KCl (CRRT) - 2 mEq./hour
   Other ICU medications:
   Famotidine (Pepcid) - [**2138-9-25**] 08:00 AM
   Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis) - [**2138-9-25**] 02:00 PM
   Lorazepam (Ativan) - [**2138-9-26**] 12:00 AM
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Transfer Note:
   Patient initially admitted to MICU [**Location (un) **] on [**9-13**] for acute renal
   failure and hyperkalemia.  Now transferred to [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for ureteral
   stenting tomorrow and possible palliative chemo on OMED.
   MICU course as below:
   74 yo F w/ Stage IV metastatic ovarian cancer, ARF on CVVH, and
   malignant pleural effusion.  Course has been complicated by
   hypotension requiring pressors (levophed).  Originally presented
   to ED [**2-22**] ARF and hyperkalemia.  PMH includes hypothyroidism and
   HLD.
   .
   #. Hypotension/shock.  Has required Levophed for much of
   admission.  Last 2-3 days prior to leaving the MICU for the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**]
   she tolerated several hours without pressors; however, she
   received albumin or blood during these periods.   Differential
   dx for shock includes sepsis, metabolic causes, cardiogenic,
   hypovolemia.
   - [**Name (NI) 1064**] pt has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile.  Started
   on empiric abx to cover for HAP.  D/c abx on [**9-25**]: pt received 6
   days of zosyn, 9 days of cipro, and 4 days of vanc.  Line
   infections: changed HD cath over the wire on [**9-23**] and art line
   was d/c
ed.  Monitored PICC line for signs of infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not adrenal
   insufficiency.  Consulted ID for evaluation of whether
   hypothyroidism could cause shock.  Increased dose of Synthroid
   and transitioned to IV but endocrinology that it is unlikely for
   hypothyroidism to be the cause. Endo also concerned because pt
   had one episode of paroxysmal a. fib on [**9-20**] and increased dose
   of synthroid may precipitate further episodes.  Will continue to
   monitor, however, this episodes appears to be isolated.
   - Cardiogenic-  Originally, was concerned for tamponade.
   Although they have been suboptimal studies, multiple echoes have
   only showed effusions without echocardiographic evidence of
   tamponade with one exception.  Her echo from [**9-15**] showed
   impaired fillling/tamponade physiology.  Most recent echo on [**9-24**]
   again did not show evidence of tamponade, just small effusion.
   also, echo on [**9-24**] revealed normal RV size and motion which made
   PE less likely.  Throughout her course in the MICU, have
   considered V/Q scan to r/o PE as a possible cause of hypotension
   however, given her echo findings, the pretest possibility
   remains equivocal.
   - On [**9-22**], SVV (from Vigileo) suggested intravascular depletion,
   and repleted pt with crystalloid and colloid.  However, she did
   not require pressors for much of that day.  For last few days
   prior to transfer to [**Hospital Unit Name 1**], have been running CVVH at a 0
   balance.  Gave albumin challenge again on [**9-25**] and her CVP bumped
   to 12 and was thus able to be off of leveophed for several
   hours. It appeared that she needs her CVP to be [**1-4**] to
   maintain her BP.  Goal has been to wean levophed and have
   considered transitioning to midodrine as an oral pressor.
   - At time of transfer, the etiology of her hypotension remains
   elusive.  Without an adequate explanation, team has hypothesized
   that this may be a possible paraneoplastic syndrome.
   .
   # Bilat pleural effusions, cytology from left c/w malignancy.
   Final cytology from right effusion still pending at time of
   transfer but pH, cell counts, gluc, prot consistent with left
   effusion and anticipate that it will also be malignant. Prior to
   first thoracentesis, pt required BiPap but upon transfer, pt has
   been satting well on only 1.5L NC for several days.
   Underwent both chest tube and pigtail placement for left sided
   effusion.  Chest tube was removed early in course of stay
   because it was extrathoracic and not draining but pigtail
   (placed by IP) continues to drain serosang fluid.  Was placed to
   water seal by IP on [**9-25**].  A repeat CT on [**9-22**] showed increased
   right sided effusion which was tapped on [**9-24**].  IP is considering
   either Pleurodesis vs pleurex when stable.  Has also used
   bronchodilators for wheezing.
   .
   #. Acute renal failure
 Persistent volume overload and
   anasarca.  Originally admitted with K of 7.8 and Cr of 7.2.
   Hyperkalemia resolved quickly (see below).  Held on dialysis for
   a few days but CVVH was started on [**9-16**] but had to be stopped
   temporarily on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.  Line changed over the wire
   by renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH. Initial and repeat imaging
   of kidneys has showed continued right hydronephrosis.  Plan is
   to transfer from MICU ([**Hospital Ward Name **]) to [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] in order to go to
   the OR with urology on [**9-26**].  Urology will place a stent in the
   right ureter.  Goal of stenting is to relieve the obstruction
   with the hope of regaining some kidney function.  Acutely on
   [**9-24**], she developed hyponatremia and hyperglycemia. Unclear
   etiology but hyponatremia may be related to the ultrafiltrate
   bath having a Na concentration of 130.  Na corrected slightly
   following initiation of insulin sliding scale for hyperglycemia.
   Also, hyperglycemia seems to have occurred acutely.  No prior
   episodes of hyperglycemia during this admission.  Also, [**Name8 (MD) **] RN,
   finger sticks are consistently lower than serum glucose.  Could
   be related to diffuse extravascular volume.  Pt was placed on
   insulin sliding scale for the elev glucose.  Initially, pt was
   hyperphosphatemic but on the day of transfer pt required
   repletion of phos.  Used Na-Phos for added sodium benefit.  Have
   held home Lasix and ACE-I in setting of ARF.
   .
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer: cardiopulmonary status has been too
   tenuous for treatment during this admission.  Obtained tumor
   markers which revealed borderline high CA-125 and elevated
   CA27,29, but were overall non-specific.  Heme onc is following
   closely and feel that pt will require inpt palliative
   chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum.  Family has been
   supportive of continuing more aggressive means of treatment.
   Have discussed transfer to OMED when stable and off pressors.
   Gyn onc originally saw the pt but have not been following daily.
   Also, on allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome.
   .
   #. Hypothyroidism
 Was diagnosed with hypothyroidism approx 2
   weeks prior to admission and had been started on a low dose of
   Synthroid. Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   Preliminary thought is no, but increased dose to 100 mcg on [**9-25**].
   Per endo, should re-check a Free T4 level in 3 to 4 days.
   Anti-TPO ab < 10.  Also, changed from oral to IV Synthroid to
   ensure proper absorption despite this one episode of
   questionable a. fib.
   .
   #. Hyperkalemia, resolved: Was most likely due to worsening
   renal function, esp in setting of the medications she was
   taking, including Lasix and ACE-I. Pt had K 7.8 on arrival to
   ED, without ECG changes. Treated w/ Ca gluconate, insulin /
   dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.  Potassium has
   appropriately responded to treatment and has remained wnl.
   .
   #. Hyperlipidemia - Taking home statin dose.
   .
   #. Code - Pt remains full code at time of transfer to [**Hospital Unit Name 1**].
   .
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:
   Cardiovascular: No(t) Chest pain, Edema, Tachycardia

Based on the patient's progress note, I have summarized the information as follows:

**Patient Information**

* Age: 74
* Sex: Female
* Admitted with: Acute Renal Failure (ARF) and hyperkalemia
* Diagnosis: Metastatic ovarian cancer
* History of: Hypothyroidism and HLD

**Current Status**

* Hypotension and shock, requiring Levophed for most of admission
* Bilateral pleural effusions, with cytology from left effusion confirming malignancy
* Acute Renal Failure (ARF) with significant volume overload and anasarca
* Hyponatremia and hyperglycemia, with unclear etiology
* Metastatic ovarian cancer, not stable for treatment at this time

**Assessment and Plan**

* Hypotension and shock: differential diagnosis includes sepsis, metabolic causes, cardiogenic, and hypovolemia
* Bilateral pleural effusions: pigtail catheter draining well, IP following pigtail
* Acute Renal Failure: CVVH started on 9/16, stopped on 9/20 due to poor access, restarted on 9/23
* Metastatic ovarian cancer: will require inpatient palliative chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum, when off pressors

**Potential Medical Complications**

* Hypotension and shock: sepsis, metabolic causes, cardiogenic, and hypovolemia
* Bilateral pleural effusions: tamponade, PE, and respiratory failure
* Acute Renal Failure: worsening renal function, electrolyte imbalance, and volume overload
* Metastatic ovarian cancer: tumor lysis syndrome, chemotherapy toxicity, and palliative care challenges

**Recommendations**

* Monitor for signs of infection in PICC line
* Continue to manage hypotension and shock with Levophed and CVVH
* Monitor for respiratory failure and consider V/Q scan to rule out PE
* Consider midodrine as an oral pressor
* Replete phosphorus and consider using Na-Phos for added sodium benefit
* Hold home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
* Consult with endocrinology to re-check free T4 levels and monitor for a. fib
* Continue to manage hyperglycemia with insulin sliding scale

**ICU Care**

* Nutrition: regular diet, NPO after midnight for ureteral stent
* Glycemic Control: sliding scale insulin
* Lines: dialysis catheter, PICC line, and prophylactic antibiotics
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following medical complications and potential issues have arisen:

1. Hypotension and shock: The patient has required Levophed for much of her admission, indicating a need for vasopressor support. The differential diagnosis for shock includes sepsis, metabolic causes, cardiogenic, and hypovolemia.
2. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient has developed ARF, which is likely related to significant volume overload and anasarca. CVVH was started on 9/16 and stopped on 9/20 due to poor access, but was restarted on 9/23.
3. Bilateral pleural effusions: The patient has developed bilateral pleural effusions, with cytology from the left effusion confirming malignancy. The right-sided effusion has increased in size, and the patient is currently being managed with a pigtail catheter and thoracentesis.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient had a potassium level of 7.8 on arrival to the ED, which was treated with calcium gluconate, insulin/dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate. The potassium level has remained within normal limits since treatment.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient has been hyponatremic, which may be related to the ultrafiltrate bath having a sodium concentration of 130. The patient has been treated with insulin sliding scale for hyperglycemia, which may also be contributing to the hyponatremia.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient has developed hyperglycemia, which is being managed with insulin sliding scale. The etiology of the hyperglycemia is unclear, but it may be related to the ultrafiltrate bath or other factors.
7. Metastatic ovarian cancer: The patient has a diagnosis of metastatic ovarian cancer, which is not currently stable for treatment. The patient will require inpatient palliative chemotherapy, and oncology would prefer that the chest tube be removed prior to chemotherapy.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which is being managed with Synthroid. The patient's thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is normal, but the free T4 level is low.
9. Anasarca: The patient has developed anasarca, which is a severe form of edema. This is likely related to the patient's underlying medical conditions and may be contributing to the patient's hypotension and shock.

The patient's current medical issues and potential complications include:

* Hypotension and shock
* Acute Renal Failure (ARF)
* Bilateral pleural effusions
* Hyperkalemia
* Hyponatremia
* Hyperglycemia
* Metastatic ovarian cancer
* Hypothyroidism
* Anasarca

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continued management of hypotension and shock with Levophed and other vasopressors as needed
* CVVH to manage ARF
* Thoracentesis and pigtail catheter placement to manage bilateral pleural effusions
* Insulin sliding scale to manage hyperglycemia
* Synthroid to manage hypothyroidism
* Palliative chemotherapy for metastatic ovarian cancer
* Monitoring for signs of infection and sepsis
* Management of anasarca with diuretics and other therapies as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-inch tall individual who weighs 141.1 kg, with a body mass index (BMI) of approximately 43.5. The patient was transferred from the MICU (West) for ureteral stent placement and is requiring continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) and low-dose norepinephrine for pressure support. The patient has a history of allergies to oxycodone and has received antibiotics, including piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin.

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 35.2°C (95.4°F), heart rate 100 beats per minute, blood pressure 87/53 mmHg, respiratory rate 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 9 mmHg, and fluid balance shows an intake of 6,337 mL and an output of 6,393 mL over the past 24 hours.

The patient's physical examination is notable for severe edema in the sacral area and lateral side of the abdomen, as well as pitting edema in both legs. The patient's neurologic examination is normal, with strength 5/5 and normal reflexes.

Laboratory results show the following:

* Potassium: 25.3 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 231 mg/dL
* Glucose: 379 mg/dL
* White blood cell count: 16.9 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 30.2%
* Platelet count: 1465
* International normalized ratio (INR): 1.2
* Partial thromboplastin time (PTT): 26.7 seconds
* Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT): 13.9 seconds
* Lactic acid: 2.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* Lipase: 26 IU/L
* Amylase: 45 IU/L
* Creatine kinase (CK): 130 IU/L
* Troponin-T: 0.9 ng/mL

Potential medical complications that may arise from this patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure due to severe edema and decreased lung compliance
* Cardiac failure due to increased afterload and decreased cardiac output
* Renal failure due to decreased renal perfusion and increased creatinine levels
* Electrolyte imbalance due to potassium and creatinine levels
* Infection due to prolonged hospitalization and presence of central venous catheters
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to immobility and presence of central venous catheters
* Stress ulcer due to prolonged critical illness and presence of central venous catheters
* Vascular access complications due to presence of central venous catheters

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with ovarian cancer who has been admitted to the ICU for management of hydronephrosis, chemotherapy, and vasopressor-dependent shock. She has been on continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) for acute renal failure. The patient has undergone several interventions, including placement of a right HD catheter, PICC line, and dialysis catheter. She is currently on multiple medications, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and medications for electrolyte imbalance.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 94 beats per minute, blood pressure of 101/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. Her respiratory support consists of nasal cannula oxygen therapy.

The patient's physical examination is significant for bilateral chest CTAs, soft abdomen, and warm, dry extremities. Her laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate levels. Her electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperphosphatemia.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Hypotension (shock): Unclear etiology, possibly related to obstructing stone and trapped bacterial infection. Plan includes ureteral stent placement, continuation of antibiotics, and re-checking cortisol levels.
2. Acute Renal Failure: Plan includes continuation of CVVH.
3. Hypothyroidism: Plan includes synthroid.
4. FEN: NPO for procedure.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to persistent infection
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) or chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to prolonged CRRT
* Hypothyroidism-related complications, such as bradycardia, hypotension, or cognitive impairment
* Electrolyte imbalance-related complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness
* Respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or gastrointestinal bleeding, due to prolonged NPO status
* Infection-related complications, such as urinary tract infections (UTIs) or central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs)

Close monitoring and management of the patient's condition are essential to prevent these complications and improve her overall outcome.

Chief Complaint: 74 year old with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian
   cancer on pressorts and [**Hospital 1460**] transferred from west to east for ureteral
   stenting and possible palliative chemo
   24 Hour Events:
   doing well, on CVVH this AM. concern for sepsis of unknown etiology.
   hypotension, on pressor. new onset hyperglycemia 1 week ago, now on
   ISS.
   -f/u endocrine recs - order free T3, T4, TSH, ftbh for tomorrow AM as
   per their recs, no mention of cortisol level being on the low end of
   normal
   -repeat cortisol (added on to [**9-26**] am labs)
   - renal fellow notes, continue on CVVH, still requiring pressors and
   hence unable to CIF. Hydronephrosis due to obstruction and plan for
   stenting, concerned that the stent will block soon after placment
   - as per urology patient is not a candidate for percutanous nephrostomy
   tube because cannot lay flat for positive.
   - went to OR today for stent placement. as per urology there is
   evidence of hydronephrosis and significant stricture close to UPJ -
   urine removed was cloudy but no definitive perinephric abscess was
   identified- sent as per urology resident for culture
   - patient post procedure came back intubated, d/c propofol drip but
   patient still requiring [**Last Name (LF) 494**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] likely be able to d/c
   - oncology notes, metastatic cancer likely ovarian, kidney failure due
   to ATN plus AIN plus/minus effects of ureteral obstruction, hypotension
   due to fluid shifts related to ca effusions vs. adreanl insufficiency -
   chemo LOW probability of cure, also risky in context of poor kidney
   failure, do not think that ureteral stent would reverse her renal
   failure. family willingness to try chemo even if results in permananent
   kidney failure and death. - if renal function improves and hypotension
   resolves will offer single [**Doctor Last Name **] chemo.
   - as per attending would consider starting steroids if patient remains
   hypotensive as patient with low-normal cortisol in the setting of what
   should be a high stress situation.
   - also wrote for patient to get 25 g of IV albumin in effort to provide
   positive intravascular colloid

   hyperkalemia.  PMH includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   #. Hypotension and shock.  Has required Levophed for much of
   admission.  Transiently able to be able to get off of pressors,
   intermittently requiring levofed.   Differential diagnsosis is likely
   mixed picture of  malignant leak, thyroid leak, septic leak.
   - [**Name (NI) 1064**] pt has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile.  Started on
   empiric abx to cover for HAP.  D/c abx today ([**9-25**]); pt received 6 days
   of zosyn, 9 days of cipro, and 4 days of vanc.  Line infections:
   changed HD cath over the wire on [**9-23**] and art line was d/c
ed.  Will
   monitor PICC line for signs of infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not adrenal insufficiency.
   Random cortisol was on the lower side. Consulted endocrinology for
   evaluation of whether hypothyroidism could cause shock.  Increased dose
   of Synthroid and transitioned to IV but endocrinology that it is
   unlikely for hypothyroidism to be the cause. Endo also concerned
   because pt had one episode of paroxysmal a. fib on [**9-20**] and increased
   dose of synthroid may precipitate further episodes.  Will continue to
   monitor, however, this episodes appears to be isolated.
   - Cardiogenic-  Repeat echo on [**9-24**] did not show evidence of tamponade,
   just small effusion.  RV size and motion was wnl; can consider V/Q scan
   to r/o PE as cause of hypotension however, given the echo findings
   there is a lower pretest probability
   - On [**9-22**], SVV suggested intravascular depletion, and repleted pt with
   crystalloid and colloid.  She continues to require levophed, can
   consider midodrine v more albumin.  Will attempt to decrease levophed
   as tolerated.
   - goal CVP 12-14
   - new thing we started steroids yesterday, as well as IV albumin
   - would re-start vanco for gram + coverage as well
   - transfuse goals to keep Hct > 30
   .
   #) Intubation for procedure
   -          not off sedation, on 5 and 5, RSBi on higher side but
   patient is large, probably at base line
   -          blood pressure stable
   -          plan to try to extubate today
   -          chest x-ray over 24 hours
   # Bilat pleural effusions, cytology from left c/w malignancy.  Left
   sided effusion improved s/p pigtail placement but CT on [**9-22**] showed
   increased right sided effusion.  Only requiring NC at this time.
   - pH on pleural fluid 6.9, chest tube in place
   - Pigtail cath draining well.  IP following pigtail
   - IP performed thoracentesis of right sided effusion on [**9-24**]
   - Pleurodesis vs pleurex when stable as per thoraric surgery, CT
   surgery also wants CT chest
   - Added standing bronchodilators for wheezing
   - f/u cytology for r-sided studies
   .
   #. Acute renal failure
 Significant vol overload and anasarca.  CVVH
   started on [**9-16**] and stopped on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.  Line replaced by
   renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH.
   - Repeat imaging of kidneys showed unchanged right hydronephrosis.
   - right ureteral procedure yesterday to open stricture.  Will be
   performed on [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**], cysto-suite.  Needs to be NPO after midnight.
   Patient is not candidate for percutaneous nephrostomy tube, due to
   anasarca; it will still need MAC.
   - Has been hyponatremic and hyperglycemia.  Unclear etiology but
   hyponatremia may be related to the ultrafiltrate bath having a Na
   concentration of 130.  Na corrected slightly following initiation of
   insulin sliding scale for hyperglycemia.  Also, hyperglycemia seems to
   have occurred acutely.  No prior episodes of hyperglycemia during this
   admission.  Also, [**Name8 (MD) **] RN, finger sticks are consistently lower than
   serum glucose.  Could be related to diffuse extravascular volume.
   Continue to monitor and use ISS as needed.
   - Replete phos today; can use Na-Phos for added sodium benefit
   - holding home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
   .
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer: at this time, not stable for treatment
   - Will require inpt palliative chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum
   - When off pressors, can be transferred to OMED
   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   - Updated gyn onc resident re pt
s current condition on [**9-25**].
   .
   #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 100 mcg.  Need to re-check a free
   T4 in several days.
   - Anti-TPO ab < 10
   - Changed from oral to IV to ensure proper absorption
   - Monitor for a. fib
   - appreciate endocrine recs
   .
   #. Hyperkalemia, resolved: Most likely due to worsening renal function,
   esp in setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and
   ACE-I. Pt had K 7.8 on arrival to ED, without ECG changes. Treated w/
   Ca gluconate, insulin / dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.
   Potassium has appropriately responded to treatment  and has remained
   wnl.
   .#. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer who was transferred to the ICU from the ED for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. She has been experiencing hypotension, requiring pressors, and has a history of acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, and hyperglycemia. The patient has been intubated and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's medical history includes hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia. She has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile. The patient has been treated with empiric antibiotics and has had a line infection, which was treated with antibiotics.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hypotension and shock, requiring pressors
* Acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL
* Hyperkalemia, which has resolved with treatment
* Hyperglycemia, which is being managed with insulin sliding scale
* Bilateral pleural effusions, with cytology showing malignancy
* Right ureteral stricture, which was treated with a ureteral stent
* Anasarca, which is preventing the placement of a percutaneous nephrostomy tube

The patient's lab results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 15.0 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 209 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL
* Glucose: 107 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.3 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis: The patient has a leukocytosis and is at risk for sepsis, particularly with the presence of a line infection.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which can progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient has a history of hyperkalemia, which can be life-threatening if not managed properly.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which can cause fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance.
* Pleural effusions: The patient has bilateral pleural effusions, which can cause respiratory distress and compromise lung function.
* Ureteral stricture: The patient has a right ureteral stricture, which can cause hydronephrosis and compromise kidney function.
* Anasarca: The patient has anasarca, which can cause respiratory distress and compromise lung function.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Pressor support to manage hypotension
* Antibiotics to treat line infection
* Insulin sliding scale to manage hyperglycemia
* Renal replacement therapy to manage acute renal failure
* Palliative chemotherapy to manage metastatic ovarian cancer
* Ureteral stent to manage right ureteral stricture
* Thoracentesis to manage pleural effusions
* Nutritional support to manage anasarca.

   - [**Name (NI) 1064**] pt has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile.  Started on
   empiric abx to cover for HAP.  D/c abx ([**9-25**]); pt received 6 days of
   zosyn, 9 days of cipro, and 4 days of vanc.  With concern for possible
   line infections: changed HD cath over the wire on [**9-23**] and art line was
   d/c
ed.  PICC line without signs of active infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not overt adrenal
   insufficiency, however random cortisol was on the lower side of normal
   especially in the context of what should be normal stress response. On

   transitioned to IV but endocrinology that it is unlikely for
   hypothyroidism to be the cause. Endo also concerned because pt had one

   percutaneous nephrostomy tube, due to anasarca; it will still need
   MAC.
   - Has been hyponatremic and hyperglycemia.  Unclear etiology but

   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome

s current condition on [**9-25**].

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, currently in the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. She has been experiencing hypotension, requiring pressors, and has a history of acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, and hypothyroidism. The patient has undergone several procedures, including ureteral stenting, and has been on various medications, including CVVH, insulin sliding scale, and IV albumin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and unknown etiology of sepsis require close monitoring and prompt treatment to prevent septic shock.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's AKI may worsen due to ongoing fluid overload, and CVVH may be necessary to manage her renal function.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status requires close monitoring, and extubation may be challenging due to her underlying condition.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen due to her underlying condition and the use of corticosteroids, requiring close monitoring and adjustment of insulin therapy.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen due to her underlying condition, and close monitoring of thyroid function is necessary to adjust her medication.
6. Ureteral Stenting: The patient's ureteral stenting may not be effective in reversing her renal failure, and further interventions may be necessary to manage her hydronephrosis.
7. Malignant Effusions: The patient's bilateral pleural effusions require close monitoring and drainage to prevent respiratory compromise.
8. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's underlying cardiovascular disease may worsen due to her underlying condition, and close monitoring of her cardiac function is necessary to prevent cardiovascular complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, and respiratory rate.
2. Adjust insulin therapy as necessary to manage the patient's hyperglycemia.
3. Monitor the patient's thyroid function and adjust her medication as necessary.
4. Continue CVVH as necessary to manage the patient's AKI.
5. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider extubation when feasible.
6. Consider further interventions to manage the patient's ureteral stenting and hydronephrosis.
7. Monitor the patient's malignant effusions and consider drainage as necessary.
8. Consider consults with cardiology and endocrinology to further manage the patient's underlying cardiovascular and thyroid conditions.

   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia.  PMH includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   #. Hypotension and shock.  Has required Levophed for much of

   intermittently requiring levofed.   Differential diagnsosis is likely
   mixed picture of  malignant fluid leak, thyroid leak, septic leak.
   - [**Name (NI) 1064**] pt has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile.  Started on
   empiric abx to cover for HAP.  D/c abx ([**9-25**]); pt received 6 days of
   zosyn, 9 days of cipro, and 4 days of vanc.  With concern for possible
   line infections: changed HD cath over the wire on [**9-23**] and art line was
   d/c
ed.  PICC line without signs of active infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not overt adrenal
   insufficiency, however random cortisol was on the lower side of normal
   especially in the context of what should be normal stress response. On
   [**9-26**] PM started IV steroids for concerns for relative adrenal
   insufficiency. Consulted endocrinology for evaluation of whether
   hypothyroidism could cause shock.  Increased dose of Synthroid and
   transitioned to IV but endocrinology that it is unlikely for
   hypothyroidism to be the cause. Endo also concerned because pt had one
   episode of paroxysmal a. fib on [**9-20**] and increased dose of synthroid
   may precipitate further episodes.  Will continue to monitor, however,
   this episodes appears to be isolated.
   - Cardiogenic-  Repeat echo on [**9-24**] did not show evidence of tamponade,
   just small effusion.  RV size and motion was wnl; can consider V/Q scan
   to r/o PE as cause of hypotension however, given the echo findings
   there is a lower pretest probability
   - On [**9-22**], SVV suggested intravascular depletion, and repleted pt with
   crystalloid and colloid.  She continues to require levophed, can
   consider midodrine v more albumin.  Will attempt to decrease levophed
   as tolerated.

   - Repeat imaging of kidneys showed unchanged right hydronephrosis.
   - right ureteral procedure yesterday to open stricture with stent.
   Culture data pending.  Needs Patient is not candidate for percutaneous

   - Has been hyponatremic and hyperglycemia.  Unclear etiology but
   hyponatremia may be related to the ultrafiltrate bath having a Na

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, who was transferred to the ICU from the west coast for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. She has been experiencing hypotension, requiring pressors, and has a history of acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, and hyperglycemia. She has undergone several procedures, including a stent placement, and has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics, steroids, and insulin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis of unknown etiology is a concern, and the possibility of line infections or other sources of infection should be investigated.
2. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient's cortisol level is on the lower side of normal, and she has been treated with IV steroids. Further evaluation by endocrinology is needed to determine the cause of her hypotension.
3. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's echocardiogram did not show evidence of tamponade, but the possibility of cardiogenic shock should be considered.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including hypovolemia, anasarca, and ATN. Further evaluation of her kidney function and possible treatment options, such as dialysis, should be considered.
5. Metastatic Cancer: The patient's metastatic ovarian cancer is a significant concern, and palliative chemotherapy should be considered. However, the patient's poor kidney function and hypotension may make it difficult to administer chemotherapy.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure, requiring intubation, is a concern, and the possibility of respiratory failure should be monitored closely.
7. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance, including hyperkalemia and hyponatremia, should be closely monitored and treated as needed.
8. Infection: The patient's infection, including the possibility of line infections, should be closely monitored and treated as needed.

Recommendations:

1. Further evaluation by endocrinology to determine the cause of the patient's hypotension.
2. Consideration of palliative chemotherapy for the patient's metastatic ovarian cancer.
3. Close monitoring of the patient's kidney function and possible treatment options, such as dialysis.
4. Monitoring of the patient's respiratory function and possible treatment options, such as non-invasive ventilation.
5. Close monitoring of the patient's electrolyte imbalance and possible treatment options, such as insulin and dextrose.
6. Investigation of the patient's sepsis of unknown etiology and possible treatment options, such as antibiotics.
7. Consideration of the patient's code status and possible treatment options, such as full code or do not resuscitate.

   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and

   hyperkalemia.  PMH includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   #. Hypotension and shock.  Patient is currently off pressors. Had an
   episode last night where she had hypotension and received albumin and 1
   unit of blood improving her symptoms. The etiology is multifactorial:
   hypothyroidism, plus cortisol insufficiency, cardiogenic shock, sepses,

   - Continue standing bronchodilators for wheezing

   started on [**9-16**] and stopped on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.  Line replaced by
   renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH. Patient doing better and may tolerate
   HD tomorrow. Stent placed 2 days ago and doing fine.
   - holding home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer: at this time, not stable for treatment
   - consider inpatient palliative chemo
   - When off pressors, consider transfer to OMED
   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   - Updated gyn onc resident re pt
s current condition on [**9-25**].

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a chief complaint of renal failure, hypotension, and anasarca. She has been admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of metastatic ovarian cancer and is currently on pressors. 

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 36.3°C, heart rate 98 bpm, blood pressure 113/78 mmHg, respiratory rate 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 100%. She is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 338 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 16 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen of 3%. 

The patient's laboratory results show anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL, elevated white blood cell count of 15.0 K/uL, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase level of 354 IU/L. Her electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypocalcemia, hypokalemia, and hyperphosphatemia. 

The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. She is also taking medications for her conditions, including a statin, a beta blocker, and an antihypertensive. 

The patient's medical complications include bilateral pleural effusions, acute renal failure, and hypotension. She has been treated with albumin and blood transfusions for her hypotension and has undergone CVVH for her acute renal failure. 

The patient's current plan includes continued treatment for her hypotension and acute renal failure, as well as ongoing management of her pleural effusions and metastatic ovarian cancer. She will also be considered for inpatient palliative chemotherapy and may be transferred to an oncology service once she is off pressors. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of hypertension and hypothyroidism increases her risk of cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure and pleural effusions increase her risk of respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, and respiratory arrest.
3. Renal complications: The patient's acute renal failure and electrolyte imbalances increase her risk of renal complications, such as sepsis, acute kidney injury, and chronic kidney disease.
4. Infectious complications: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of indwelling catheters increase her risk of infectious complications, such as sepsis, pneumonia, and urinary tract infections.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of hypothyroidism and electrolyte imbalances increase her risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, who was transferred to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. She has a complex medical history, including hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, and a recent episode of acute renal failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Renal failure: The patient has been on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) since September 16th, and was restarted on September 23rd after a line replacement. Her creatinine levels have been fluctuating between 0.9-1.1 mg/dL.
* Hypotension and shock: The patient has been on pressors, but is currently off them. She had an episode of hypotension last night, which was treated with albumin and 1 unit of blood. The etiology of her hypotension is multifactorial, including hypothyroidism, cortisol insufficiency, cardiogenic shock, and sepsis.
* Bilateral pleural effusions: The patient has a chest tube in place, and a pigtail catheter draining well. A CT scan on September 22nd showed an increased right-sided effusion.
* Anasarca: The patient has severe pitting edema, particularly in the sacral area and lateral walls of the abdomen.
* Metastatic ovarian cancer: The patient is not stable for treatment at this time, but may be considered for inpatient palliative chemotherapy in the future.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and low cardiac output can lead to cardiogenic shock, which can be life-threatening.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can worsen her hypotension and lead to organ dysfunction.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure can worsen if not managed properly, leading to electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's bilateral pleural effusions can worsen her respiratory status, leading to respiratory failure.
* Malnutrition: The patient's anasarca and respiratory failure can lead to malnutrition, which can worsen her overall condition.
* Infection: The patient's anasarca and respiratory failure can increase her risk of infection, which can worsen her condition.

Based on the patient's current condition, the following plan should be implemented:

* Monitor the patient's blood pressure and cardiac output closely to prevent cardiogenic shock.
* Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and source control.
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her fluid management accordingly.
* Continue to manage the patient's bilateral pleural effusions with chest tube drainage and pigtail catheter placement.
* Consider inpatient palliative chemotherapy for the patient's metastatic ovarian cancer.
* Monitor the patient's anasarca and respiratory status closely to prevent malnutrition and respiratory failure.
* Consider prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection.

   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia.  PMH includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   #. Hypotension and shock.  Has required Levophed for much of
   admission.  Transiently able to be able to get off of pressors,
   intermittently requiring levofed.   Differential diagnsosis is likely
   mixed picture of  malignant fluid leak, thyroid leak, septic leak.
   - [**Name (NI) 1064**] pt has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile.  Started on
   empiric abx to cover for HAP.  D/c abx ([**9-25**]); pt received 6 days of
   zosyn, 9 days of cipro, and 4 days of vanc.  With concern for possible
   line infections: changed HD cath over the wire on [**9-23**] and art line was
   d/c
ed.  PICC line without signs of active infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not overt adrenal
   insufficiency, however random cortisol was on the lower side of normal
   especially in the context of what should be normal stress response. On
   [**9-26**] PM started IV steroids for concerns for relative adrenal
   insufficiency. Consulted endocrinology for evaluation of whether
   hypothyroidism could cause shock.  Increased dose of Synthroid and
   transitioned to IV but endocrinology that it is unlikely for
   hypothyroidism to be the cause. Endo also concerned because pt had one
   episode of paroxysmal a. fib on [**9-20**] and increased dose of synthroid
   may precipitate further episodes.  Will continue to monitor, however,
   this episodes appears to be isolated.
   - Cardiogenic-  Repeat echo on [**9-24**] did not show evidence of tamponade,
   just small effusion.  RV size and motion was wnl; can consider V/Q scan
   to r/o PE as cause of hypotension however, given the echo findings
   there is a lower pretest probability
   - On [**9-22**], SVV suggested intravascular depletion, and repleted pt with
   crystalloid and colloid.  She continues to require levophed, can
   consider midodrine v more albumin.  Will attempt to decrease levophed
   as tolerated.
   - goal CVP 12-14
   - new thing we started steroids yesterday, as well as IV albumin
   - would re-start vanco for gram + coverage as well
   - transfuse goals to keep Hct > 30
   #) Intubation for procedure
   -          not off sedation, on 5 and 5, RSBi on higher side but
   patient is large, probably at base line
   -          blood pressure stable
   -          plan to try to extubate today
   -          chest x-ray over 24 hours
   # Bilat pleural effusions, cytology from left c/w malignancy.  Left
   sided effusion improved s/p pigtail placement but CT on [**9-22**] showed
   increased right sided effusion.  Only requiring NC at this time.
   - pH on pleural fluid 6.9, chest tube in place
   - Pigtail cath draining well.  IP following pigtail
   - IP performed thoracentesis of right sided effusion on [**9-24**]
   - Pleurodesis vs pleurex when stable as per thoraric surgery, CT
   surgery also wants CT chest
   - Added standing bronchodilators for wheezing
   - f/u cytology for r-sided studies
   #. Acute renal failure
 Significant vol overload and anasarca.  CVVH
   started on [**9-16**] and stopped on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.  Line replaced by
   renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH.
   - Repeat imaging of kidneys showed unchanged right hydronephrosis.
   - right ureteral procedure yesterday to open stricture with stent.
   Culture data pending.  Needs Patient is not candidate for percutaneous
   nephrostomy tube, due to anasarca
   - Has been hyponatremic and hyperglycemia.  Unclear etiology but
   hyponatremia may be related to the ultrafiltrate bath having a Na
   concentration of 130.  Na corrected slightly following initiation of
   insulin sliding scale for hyperglycemia.  Also, hyperglycemia seems to
   have occurred acutely.  No prior episodes of hyperglycemia during this
   admission.  Also, [**Name8 (MD) **] RN, finger sticks are consistently lower than
   serum glucose.  Could be related to diffuse extravascular volume.
   Continue to monitor and use ISS as needed.
   - Replete phos today; can use Na-Phos for added sodium benefit
   - holding home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer: at this time, not stable for treatment
   - consider inpatient palliative chemo
   - When off pressors, consider transfer to OMED
   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   - Updated gyn onc resident re pt
s current condition on [**9-25**].
   .#. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 100 mcg.  Need to re-check a free
   T4 in several days.
   - Anti-TPO ab < 10
   - Changed from oral to IV to ensure proper absorption
   - Monitor for a. fib
   - follow up endocrine rec

   #. Hyperkalemia, resolved: Most likely due to worsening renal function,
   esp in setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and

1. Malignant fluid leak: The patient has a history of metastatic ovarian cancer, and the presence of bilateral pleural effusions with malignant cytology suggests a malignant fluid leak. This can lead to respiratory distress, hypotension, and even cardiac arrest.
2. Septic shock: The patient has a history of sepsis, and the presence of a leukocytosis and hypotension suggests that septic shock is a possibility. This can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, and the presence of a low free T4 level suggests that hypothyroidism may be contributing to the patient's hypotension and other symptoms.
4. Cardiogenic shock: The patient has a history of cardiac arrhythmias, and the presence of a small pleural effusion on the right side suggests that cardiogenic shock may be a possibility. This can lead to hypotension, cardiac arrest, and even death.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of bilateral pleural effusions, and the presence of a small effusion on the left side suggests that respiratory failure may be a possibility. This can lead to hypoxia, respiratory acidosis, and even death.
6. Acute kidney injury: The patient has a history of acute kidney injury, and the presence of a small effusion on the right side suggests that acute kidney injury may be a possibility. This can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and even death.
7. Infection: The patient has a history of sepsis, and the presence of a leukocytosis and hypotension suggests that infection may be a possibility. This can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
8. Hemodynamic instability: The patient has a history of hemodynamic instability, and the presence of a small effusion on the right side suggests that hemodynamic instability may be a possibility. This can lead to hypotension, cardiac arrest, and even death.
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient has a history of malnutrition, and the presence of a small effusion on the right side suggests that nutritional deficiencies may be a possibility. This can lead to weakness, fatigue, and even death.
10. Psychological distress: The patient has a history of psychological distress, and the presence of a small effusion on the right side suggests that psychological distress may be a possibility. This can lead to anxiety, depression, and even suicidal thoughts.

These are just a few potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's progress note. It is important to note that each patient is unique, and the actual complications that arise may be different from those listed above.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-inch tall individual with a current weight of 109.2 kg, who was admitted with renal failure, hypotension, and anasarca. The patient was extubated from invasive ventilation and is currently on nasal cannula oxygen therapy with CPAP/PSV ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 98-130 bpm, blood pressure of 113/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's temperature is 36.3°C, and they are tachycardic.

The patient has undergone several interventions, including transfusions of packed red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma, as well as treatment with albumin and vasopressors to manage hypotension. The patient has also received antibiotics, including vancomycin, and has been prescribed medications such as famotidine, lorazepam, and heparin sodium.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 27.9 mg/dL. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.5 mEq/L and a phosphorus level of 2.4 mg/dL.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their unstable condition, but they do not have any signs of peripheral vascular disease or skin changes.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Worsening of renal failure, potentially leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
2. Hypotension, potentially leading to organ dysfunction or failure.
3. Anasarca, potentially leading to respiratory compromise or cardiac failure.
4. Infection, potentially leading to sepsis or organ failure.
5. Bleeding complications, potentially leading to hypovolemic shock.
6. Cardiovascular complications, potentially leading to cardiac failure or arrhythmias.
7. Respiratory complications, potentially leading to respiratory failure or pneumonia.
8. Nutritional deficiencies, potentially leading to malnutrition or impaired wound healing.
9. Gastrointestinal complications, potentially leading to nausea, vomiting, or gastrointestinal bleeding.

It is essential to continue close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination findings to identify any potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent further deterioration.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, who was transferred to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. She was initially presented to the emergency department with acute renal failure and hyperkalemia. The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia. She is currently off pressors and has had an episode of hypotension, which was improved with albumin and blood transfusion.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Hypotension and shock: The patient has had an episode of hypotension and is at risk for further episodes due to her underlying medical conditions and medications.
2. Bilateral pleural effusions: The patient has a left-sided effusion that has improved with pigtail placement, but the right-sided effusion remains increased.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient has significant volume overload and anasarca, and has required CVVH.
4. Metastatic ovarian cancer: The patient's cancer is not stable for treatment, and she is being considered for inpatient palliative chemotherapy.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is being managed with levothyroxine, but it is unclear if it is contributing to her persistent hypotension.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient is being continued on a statin dose to manage her hyperlipidemia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to her underlying medical conditions and the presence of bilateral pleural effusions.
2. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is a potential complication of her underlying medical conditions and medications.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's bilateral pleural effusions and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) are potential complications that could lead to respiratory failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is a potential complication that could lead to further kidney damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her underlying medical conditions and the presence of bilateral pleural effusions.
6. Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to her underlying medical conditions and the presence of bilateral pleural effusions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to assess for signs of sepsis, cardiogenic shock, and respiratory failure.
2. Consider adding antibiotics to the patient's regimen to prevent infection.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hypothyroidism with levothyroxine and monitor for signs of hypothyroidism.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hyperlipidemia with a statin dose.
5. Consider adding a diuretic to the patient's regimen to help manage her volume overload.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider adding a renal-dose diuretic to the patient's regimen if necessary.

Summary:

The patient, a 74-year-old female, is in the ICU with a chief complaint of hypotension. She was transferred from the west ICU to the [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. She has a history of metastatic ovarian cancer, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia. She is currently on CVVH and has been off pressors since stent placement. Her urine output remains low, and she has a high output drainage through her chest tube.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Renal failure: Despite improvement since stent placement, the patient's urine output has not increased, and she may be at risk for further kidney damage.
2. Pleural effusions: The patient's high output drainage through her chest tube may not resolve promptly, and further evaluation and management are needed.
3. Aspiration: The patient's recent episode of aspiration highlights the risk of respiratory compromise and the need for close monitoring and further evaluation.
4. Hypotension and shock: Although the patient is off pressors, she may still be at risk for hypotension and shock, particularly if her blood pressure decreases further.
5. Metastatic ovarian cancer: The patient's cancer is not stable for treatment, and further evaluation and management are needed to determine the best course of action.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be contributing to her persistent hypotension, and further evaluation and management are needed to optimize her thyroid hormone levels.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may be contributing to her risk of cardiovascular complications, and further evaluation and management are needed to optimize her lipid levels.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and further evaluation to determine the best course of action for her care.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's current condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient remains critically ill and is being treated in the ICU.
* Renal failure is ongoing, with urine output not improving since the procedure.
* Hypotension has resolved, but the patient is still at risk due to underlying infection and potential contributing factors.
* Pleural effusions are present, and the plan is to insert an intercostal catheter for drainage.
* The patient is experiencing hypoxia and is being weaned off oxygen as tolerated.
* The patient is NPO (nothing by mouth) and is undergoing speech and swallow evaluation.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Continued renal failure, potentially leading to worsening acid-base imbalance, electrolyte disturbances, and fluid overload.
* Infection, particularly unrelieved infection, which could lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and increased risk of mortality.
* Pleural effusions, which could lead to respiratory compromise, cardiac tamponade, and worsening hypoxia.
* Hypoxia, which could lead to respiratory failure, cardiac arrhythmias, and increased risk of mortality.
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and aspiration, which could lead to respiratory compromise and increased risk of mortality.
* Cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, and cardiac arrest, which could lead to increased risk of mortality.

**Ongoing Management:**

* Close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to assess for any changes in the patient's condition.
* Continuation of CVVH and consideration of switching to hemodialysis to improve renal function.
* Ongoing antibiotic therapy to address underlying infection.
* Close monitoring of fluid balance and electrolyte levels to prevent complications.
* Weaning of oxygen therapy as tolerated to minimize respiratory compromise.
* Ongoing speech and swallow evaluation to ensure safe oral intake.
* Close communication with the patient's family and healthcare team to ensure that all parties are aware of the patient's condition and any changes.

Chief Complaint: metastatic cancer leading to acute renal failure s/p
   ureteteral stent
   [**54**] Hour Events:
   Patient on CVVH for most of day yesterday, then as per renal to start
   gettting HD instead of CVVH. concern that pulling fluid off might cause
   hypotension pressures roughly around 100 today. got HD overnight, took
   off 800 cc.
   - goal was to consider call out today pending okay blood pressure post
   dialysis
   - not good candidate now for pleuradesis
   - speech and swallow reccomending regular diet with thin liquids
   - initially was off pressors, however s/p dialysis had to restart
   levofed to maintain pressures
   - no new endocrine recs, no new urology or oncology notes in the chart
   - restarted her for marginal pressures on albumin 25 mg IV and also 50
   IV q 6 of hydrocortisone
   - put patient in for EKG in AM for persistent tachycardia
   - overnight consulted cardiology as patient was persistently
   tachycardic to 130-150s, cardiology felt that this most likely looked
   like NSVT, patient lytes were repleted aggressively, started on
   amiodarone IV load, underlying rythm is narrow complex tachycardia that
   seems to degenerate into wide complex for a few beats - differential
   includes MAT vs.
   - s/p dialysis with tachycardia and beats of vtac (most = 7) in a row,
   patient maintained blood pressure, then dropped pressure to 80/50s.
   nurse felt that patient extremetly dry, gave 250 cc bolus of NS to
   replete fluids (-800 cc removed at dialysis) then another 250 cc to
   replace some of fluid taken off during dialysis

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 54-year-old individual with metastatic cancer leading to acute renal failure, who has undergone ureteral stenting and is currently in the ICU.

The patient has been receiving continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) and has recently been transitioned to hemodialysis (HD) due to concerns about fluid removal causing hypotension. The patient's blood pressure has been around 100 mmHg, and they have required the restart of vasopressors to maintain blood pressure.

The patient has also been experiencing persistent tachycardia, which was initially thought to be atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, but was later determined to be narrow complex tachycardia that occasionally degenerates into wide complex tachycardia. The patient was started on amiodarone IV load and has been repleted with electrolytes.

The patient has undergone dialysis, and post-dialysis, they experienced a drop in blood pressure to 80/50 mmHg, which was treated with a 250 cc bolus of normal saline. The patient's fluid balance has been monitored, and they have lost a significant amount of fluid over the past 24 hours.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and increased lactate levels. Their electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low potassium level.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.4°F, heart rate of 99 bpm, and blood pressure of 113/78 mmHg. Their respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and their oxygen saturation is 98%.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been around 100 mmHg, and they have required vasopressors to maintain blood pressure. This could indicate a risk of hypotension, which could lead to decreased organ perfusion and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Tachycardia: The patient's persistent tachycardia could be a sign of underlying cardiac disease or electrolyte imbalance. This could lead to arrhythmias, decreased cardiac output, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Fluid overload: The patient has lost a significant amount of fluid over the past 24 hours, which could lead to fluid overload and potentially life-threatening complications such as pulmonary edema or cardiac failure.
4. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count could indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Metastatic cancer progression: The patient's metastatic cancer could continue to progress, leading to further complications and potentially life-threatening outcomes.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications.

   - patient had been off and on pressorts, now needing pressors again s/p
   dialysis yesterday afternoon, pressures look good this morning so will
   attemp to wean off
   - cont IV albumin
   - cont IV steroids for relative adrenal insufficiency
   - difficult fluid status
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer: at this time, not stable for treatment
   - consider inpatient palliative chemo
   - When off pressors and on HD, consider transfer to OMED
   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   - Updated gyn onc resident re pt
s current condition on [**9-25**].
   .#. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - Monitor for a. fib, on thyroid replacement
   - steroids as above

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic ovarian cancer, acute renal failure, and hypothyroidism. She was recently transferred to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Renal failure: Urine output has not improved significantly since stent placement, and creatinine levels are normal. The patient has had an episode of hypotension that may limit her ability to undergo hemodialysis.
* Pleural effusions: The patient has high-output pleural effusions on the left side, which may not be resolved promptly due to the malignant etiology.
* Aspiration: The patient is on a regular diet with thin liquids, as recommended by speech and swallow therapy.
* Hypotension and shock: The patient had been off and on pressors, but now needs them again after dialysis yesterday afternoon. She is currently receiving IV albumin and steroids for relative adrenal insufficiency.
* Metastatic ovarian cancer: The patient is not stable for treatment at this time and is being considered for inpatient palliative chemotherapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is not improving, and she may require ongoing dialysis.
2. Hypotension and shock: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and she may experience recurrent episodes of hypotension and shock.
3. Pleural effusions: The patient's pleural effusions may not resolve promptly, which could lead to respiratory compromise and other complications.
4. Aspiration: The patient may be at risk for aspiration due to her high-output pleural effusions and altered mental status.
5. Metastatic ovarian cancer: The patient's cancer may continue to progress, leading to further complications and decreased quality of life.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may not be adequately managed, leading to further complications such as fatigue, weakness, and cold intolerance.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may not be adequately managed, leading to further complications such as pancreatitis and cardiovascular disease.

In terms of assessment and plan, the patient is currently receiving treatment for her acute renal failure, pleural effusions, and hypotension. She is also being considered for inpatient palliative chemotherapy and has been referred to oncology and endocrinology for further evaluation and management.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, acute renal failure, and hypothyroidism. She was transferred to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. The patient's condition has been complicated by hypotension, which has limited her ability to undergo hemodialysis (HD). She has been on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) but has been switched to HD with the goal of improving her fluid status. The patient's electrolyte levels are being closely monitored, and she is receiving IV albumin and steroids to help maintain oncotic pressure and prevent relative adrenal insufficiency.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypotension and Shock: The patient's hypotension is a significant concern, and the use of pressors and IV albumin may not be sufficient to maintain her blood pressure. Further measures may be needed to address this issue.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and her urine output has not improved significantly since the ureteral stent was placed. Further interventions may be necessary to improve her renal function.
3. Metastatic Ovarian Cancer: The patient's cancer is metastatic, and her condition is not stable for treatment. Further discussions with the oncology team are needed to determine the best course of action.
4. Pleural Effusions: The patient has high-output pleural effusions, which may be contributing to her hypotension and respiratory compromise. Further evaluation and management of these effusions may be necessary.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be contributing to her hypotension and other symptoms. Further evaluation and management of this condition may be necessary.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia, which may be a risk factor for cardiovascular complications. Further management of this condition may be necessary.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her compromised immune system and the presence of central lines. Close monitoring and prompt treatment of any signs of infection are necessary.
8. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's tachycardia and wide complex tachycardia may be indicative of cardiac complications. Further evaluation and management of these conditions may be necessary.
9. Respiratory Complications: The patient's pleural effusions and respiratory compromise may be contributing to her respiratory distress. Further evaluation and management of these conditions may be necessary.
10. Nutritional Complications: The patient's compromised nutritional status may be contributing to her overall condition. Further evaluation and management of her nutritional needs may be necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, who was transferred to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which has not improved significantly since the ureteral stent was placed. The patient's creatinine level is normal, but the urine output has not increased.
* Tachycardia: The patient has been experiencing persistent tachycardia, which was initially thought to be sinus tachycardia, but later diagnosed as non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT). The patient was started on amiodarone IV, which has been effective in controlling the arrhythmia.
* Pleural effusions: The patient has high-output pleural effusions, which are likely due to malignancy and may not resolve promptly. The patient is not a candidate for pleuradesis.
* Aspiration: The patient has been on a regular diet with thin liquids, as recommended by speech and swallow therapy.
* Hypotension and shock: The patient has been experiencing hypotension and shock, which has been managed with IV albumin and steroids. The patient has been responsive to these medications.
* Infectious work-up: The patient has had a negative infectious work-up, including blood cultures, pleural fluid culture, and urine culture, which grew only yeast.
* Metastatic ovarian cancer: The patient's cancer is not stable for treatment at this time, and the oncology team is considering inpatient palliative chemotherapy.

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 27.9
* Hemoglobin: 9.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 247
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 28 mg/dL
* Sodium: 140 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.5 mEq/L
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.1 mg/dL
* Albumin: 3.1 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.6 mmol/L
* LDH: 398 IU/L

The patient's medications include:

* Norepinephrine: 0.08 mcg/Kg/min
* Amiodarone: 1 mg/min
* Lorazepam (Ativan): 10 mg IV
* Allopurinol: 300 mg PO
* Statin: 20 mg PO

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing IV albumin and steroids for hypotension and shock
* Considering HD again tomorrow
* Transferring the patient out of the unit pending HD tomorrow
* Considering albumin for hypotension
* Monitoring for a fib and on thyroid replacement
* Continuing steroids at current dose for now, with consideration of steroid taper starting tomorrow
* Elevated white blood cell count in the setting of IV steroids does not suspect new infection
* Considering inpatient palliative chemotherapy for metastatic ovarian cancer
* Oncology team prefers chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
* Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
* Updated gyn onc resident re pt's current condition on [**9-25**].

The patient is a 58-inch-tall, 109.2 kg (overweight/obese) individual with a history of ovarian cancer, currently in the ICU. The patient experienced hypotension and tachyarrythmia during hemodialysis, which responded to treatment with fluids, albumin, and steroids. The patient is currently receiving norepinephrine and amiodarone infusions. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2°C, heart rate of 84 bpm, and blood pressure of 113/78 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension may be related to underlying infection, sepsis, or other underlying conditions. Repeat urinalysis may be necessary to determine if an underlying infection is contributing to the patient's hypotension.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and they require hemodialysis. The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and their urine output is decreased.
3. Tachyarrythmia: The patient's tachyarrythmia may be related to underlying cardiac conditions, electrolyte imbalances, or medication side effects. The patient's amiodarone infusion may help stabilize their heart rhythm.
4. Ovarian Cancer: The patient's underlying ovarian cancer may be progressing, and their condition may worsen over time.
5. Fluid Overload: The patient has received a significant amount of fluid, which may lead to fluid overload and worsening of their respiratory and cardiovascular status.
6. Respiratory Complications: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but they may be at risk for respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), due to their underlying condition and hospitalization.
7. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac status is stable, but they may be at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest, due to their underlying condition and hospitalization.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address their multiple medical complications and underlying conditions.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with multiple medical conditions. They have been receiving various medications and treatments, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and sedatives. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2°C, heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure of 113/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with a respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute and an ABG showing a pH of 7.36.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 28 mg/dL. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with hypokalemia (potassium level of 3.5 mEq/L) and hypocalcemia (calcium level of 8.3 mg/dL). The patient's liver function tests are also elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 18 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 18 IU/L.

The patient's medical conditions include hypotension, tachyarrhythmia, and acute kidney injury. The patient is also at risk for developing respiratory failure, sepsis, and cardiac arrest.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Further deterioration of kidney function, leading to the need for dialysis.
2. Development of sepsis or septic shock, which can lead to organ failure and death.
3. Respiratory failure, which can lead to the need for mechanical ventilation.
4. Cardiac arrest, which can be life-threatening.
5. Development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE), which can lead to life-threatening complications.
6. Development of stress ulcers, which can lead to bleeding and hemorrhage.
7. Development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which can lead to sepsis and death.

The patient's plan of care includes continued monitoring and management of their vital signs, laboratory results, and medical conditions. The patient will also require ongoing treatment for their acute kidney injury, hypotension, and tachyarrhythmia. The patient's family will also need to be educated on the patient's condition and the potential complications that can arise.
