   Assessment and Plan
   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia.  PMH includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   # Renal failure: seems Urine output has not improved significantly
   since stent placement. Cr normal. Patient with episode of hypotension
   that seems to limit ability to do HD. Also seems to have tenous volume
   status.
   - CVVH stopped had first trial of HD with drop in blood pressure, plan
   for HD today 1 hour after initiation of chemotherapy at noon
   - consider IV albumin for hypotension as patient with low oncotic
   pressure
   - s/p stent to ureter to relieve obstruction which did not result in
   increased urinary output
   - urine cx sent intraoperative only growing yeast, urine apparently was
   cloudy, however no evidence of frank pus or abscess, not currently on
   any antibiotics - ordered repeat UA and uculture yesterday, not yet
   sent, will follow-up with results
   # Likely Metastatic ovarian cancer
   - will start chemo today with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of 1.66.
   first dose today, consider second dose in 21 days
   - premedication with anti-emeteics including ondansetron, dexamethasone
   today and for 3 days following chemo, dexamethasone OK even in addition
   to IV hydrocortisone as per oncology
   - seen by onc yesterday, feel that renal failure and hypotension are
   all related to fluid shifts secondary to malignancy and that the only
   way that she will be able to come off of pressors and HD is to treat
   the cancer
   - still with chest tube in (malignant effusion)
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   - onc to write orders for chemo today, written for zofran for nausea as
   well as dexamethasone pretreatment for chemotherapy
   # Tachycardia
   -  took multiple EKGs during episode of tachycardia to 130-140s (two
   nights ago). Initial arrythmia looked sinus vs. atrial tachycardia
   which appeared to transition to NSVT, faxed EKGs to cardiology fellow
   overnight, thought was consistent with NSVT, started patient on
   amiodarone IV with adequate reponse, -  during this episode rebolused
   patient with 2x 250 cc fluid for hypotension and tachycardia
   - patient was on IV amiodarone, has not been started on PO amiodarone,
   may hold off for now, and see how patient does (NSVT may have been
   secondary to dialysis in particular rapid electrolyte shifts and fluid
   loss)
   - hold off on cards consults b/c suspect that mostly due to rapid fluid
   shifts, definitely was admiodarone responsive
   - would consider official consult if patient goes back into this rhythm
   again
   #Pleural effusions: Patient still with  output through left tube. Since
   etiology is malignancy may not resolve promptly.
   - likely not candidate for pleuradesis at this time, can follow up with
   thoracics at a later date regarding plan for tube
   - effusions may be contributing to underlying heart physiology
    #. Hypotension and shock.
   - infectious work-up has been negative thus far, blood cultures no
   growth to date, pleural fluid with negative culture, urine cx grew only
   yeast
   - sent repeat UA and culture -
   - patient had been off and on pressors, overnight required again, now
   again weaned off
   With continued hypotension two days ago, got IV albumin and also IV
   steroids has has been steroid responsive  previously, again patient
   with good response
   - given that patient to start chemo today , will not taper steroids
   right away, will begin taper tomorrow (tomorrow go to 25 mg IV q
   6hours)
   - elevated white blood cell count in the setting of IV steroids as per
   above do not suspect new infection
    #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - Monitor for a. fib, on thyroid replacement
   - steroids as above
    #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # Aspiration: on regular diet with thin liquids seen by speech and
   swallow
   Dispo: ICU for HD and chemo today
    Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin
   Lines:
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2138-9-13**] 07:30 PM
   PICC Line - [**2138-9-20**] 05:07 PM

   DVT: hep subq
   Stress ulcer: h2 blocker

   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia.  PMH includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   # Renal failure: seems Urine output has not improved significantly
   since stent placement. Cr normal. Patient with episode of hypotension
   that seems to limit ability to do HD. Also seems to have tenous volume
   status.
   - CVVH stopped had first trial of HD with drop in blood pressure, plan
   for HD today 1 hour after initiation of chemotherapy at noon
   - consider IV albumin for hypotension as patient with low oncotic
   pressure
   - s/p stent to ureter to relieve obstruction which did not result in
   increased urinary output
   - urine cx sent intraoperative only growing yeast, urine apparently was
   cloudy, however no evidence of frank pus or abscess, not currently on
   any antibiotics - ordered repeat UA and uculture yesterday, not yet
   sent, will follow-up with results
   # Likely Metastatic ovarian cancer
   - will start chemo today with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of 1.66.
   first dose today, consider second dose in 21 days
   - premedication with anti-emeteics including ondansetron, dexamethasone
   today and for 3 days following chemo, dexamethasone OK even in addition
   to IV hydrocortisone as per oncology
   - seen by onc yesterday, feel that renal failure and hypotension are
   all related to fluid shifts secondary to malignancy and that the only
   way that she will be able to come off of pressors and HD is to treat
   the cancer
   - still with chest tube in (malignant effusion)
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   - onc to write orders for chemo today, written for zofran for nausea as
   well as dexamethasone pretreatment for chemotherapy
   # Tachycardia
   -  took multiple EKGs during episode of tachycardia to 130-140s (two
   nights ago). Initial arrythmia looked sinus vs. atrial tachycardia
   which appeared to transition to NSVT, faxed EKGs to cardiology fellow
   overnight, thought was consistent with NSVT, started patient on
   amiodarone IV with adequate reponse, -  during this episode rebolused
   patient with 2x 250 cc fluid for hypotension and tachycardia
   - patient was on IV amiodarone, has not been started on PO amiodarone,
   may hold off for now, and see how patient does (NSVT may have been
   secondary to dialysis in particular rapid electrolyte shifts and fluid
   loss)
   - hold off on cards consults b/c suspect that mostly due to rapid fluid
   shifts, definitely was admiodarone responsive
   - would consider official consult if patient goes back into this rhythm
   again
   #Pleural effusions: Patient still with  output through left tube. Since
   etiology is malignancy may not resolve promptly.
   - likely not candidate for pleuradesis at this time, can follow up with
   thoracics at a later date regarding plan for tube
   - effusions may be contributing to underlying heart physiology
    #. Hypotension and shock.
   - infectious work-up has been negative thus far, blood cultures no
   growth to date, pleural fluid with negative culture, urine cx grew only
   yeast
   - sent repeat UA and culture -
   - patient had been off and on pressors, overnight required again, now
   again weaned off
   With continued hypotension two days ago, got IV albumin and also IV
   steroids has has been steroid responsive  previously, again patient
   with good response
   - given that patient to start chemo today , will not taper steroids
   right away, will begin taper tomorrow (tomorrow go to 25 mg IV q
   6hours)
   - elevated white blood cell count in the setting of IV steroids as per
   above do not suspect new infection
    #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - Monitor for a. fib, on thyroid replacement
   - steroids as above
    #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # Aspiration: on regular diet with thin liquids seen by speech and
   swallow
   Dispo: ICU for HD and chemo today
    Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin
   Lines:
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2138-9-13**] 07:30 PM
   PICC Line - [**2138-9-20**] 05:07 PM

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, who was admitted to the ICU with acute renal failure and hyperkalemia. She underwent ureteral stenting and CVVH, and is currently on pressors and hemodialysis. The patient is scheduled to start chemotherapy today and has a history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Renal Failure: The patient's urine output has not improved significantly since stent placement, and her creatinine levels are normal. This may indicate ongoing renal damage or chronic kidney disease.
2. Hypotension and Shock: The patient has experienced multiple episodes of hypotension, which may be related to fluid shifts secondary to malignancy or other underlying conditions. The patient's response to IV albumin and steroids suggests that hypotension may be related to fluid and electrolyte imbalances.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be related to NSVT, which was responsive to amiodarone. The patient's EKGs showed sinus tachycardia and NSVT, which may be secondary to rapid electrolyte shifts and fluid loss during dialysis.
4. Pleural Effusions: The patient has a large pleural effusion, which may not resolve promptly due to the underlying malignancy. This may contribute to underlying heart physiology and increase the risk of respiratory compromise.
5. Infection: The patient's blood cultures and urine culture have been negative, but the patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may indicate an underlying infection. The patient's response to IV steroids may suggest that the elevated white blood cell count is not related to a new infection.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be contributing to her hypotension and may require further management with thyroid replacement therapy.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may require ongoing management with a statin, and may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications.
8. Aspiration: The patient's aspiration risk is high due to her underlying malignancy and may require further management with speech and swallow therapy.

Based on the patient's progress note, it is recommended that the patient's therapy be closely monitored and adjusted as needed to address these potential medical complications.

   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia.  PMH includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   # Renal failure: seems Urine output has not improved significantly
   since stent placement. Cr normal. Patient with episode of hypotension
   that seems to limit ability to do HD. Also seems to have tenous volume
   status.
   - CVVH stopped had first trial of HD with drop in blood pressure, plan
   for HD today 1 hour after initiation of chemotherapy
   - consider IV albumin for hypotension as patient with low oncotic
   pressure
   - s/p stent to ureter to relieve obstruction which did not result in
   increased urinary output
   - urine cx sent intraoperative only growing yeast, urine apparently was
   cloudy, however no evidence of frank pus or abscess, not currently on
   any antibiotics - sent repeat UA and uculture yesterday, will follow-up
   with results
   # Likely Metastatic ovarian cancer
   - will start chemo today with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of 1.66.
   first dose today, consider second dose in 21 days
   - premedication with anti-emeteics including ondansetron, dexamethasone
   today and for 3 days following chemo
   - seen by onc yesterday, feel that renal failure and hypotension are
   all related to fluid shifts secondary to malignancy and that the only
   way that she will be able to come off of pressors and HD is to treat
   the cancer
   - still with chest tube in (malignant effusion)
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   - onc to write orders for chemo today, written for zofran for nausea as
   well as dexamethasone pretreatment for chemotherapy
   # Tachycardia
   -  took multiple EKGs during episode of tachycardia to 130-140s (two
   nights ago). Initial arrythmia looked sinus vs. atrial tachycardia
   which appeared to transition to NSVT, faxed EKGs to cardiology fellow
   overnight, thought was consistent with NSVT, started patient on
   amiodarone IV with adequate reponse
   - patient was on IV amiodarone, has not been started on PO amiodarone,
   may hold off for now, and see how patient does (NSVT may have been
   secondary to dialysis in particular rapid electrolyte shifts and fluid
   loss)
   -  during this episode rebolused patient with 2x 250 cc fluid for
   hypotension and tachycardia
   #Pleural effusions: Patient still with  output through left tube. Since
   etiology is malignancy may not resolve promptly.
   - likely not candidate for pleuradesis at this time, can follow up with
   thoracics at a later date regarding plan for tube
   - effusions may be contributing to underlying heart physiology
    #. Hypotension and shock.
   - infectious work-up has been negative thus far, blood cultures no
   growth to date, pleural fluid with negative culture, urine cx grew only
   yeast
   - sent repeat UA and culture -
   - patient had been off and on pressors, overnight required again, now
   again weaned off
   With continued hypotension two days ago, got IV albumin and also IV
   steroids has has been steroid responsive  previously, again patient
   with good response
   - start steroid taper todoay
   - elevated white blood cell count in the setting of IV steroids as per
   above do not suspect new infection
    #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - Monitor for a. fib, on thyroid replacement
   - steroids as above
    #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # Aspiration: on regular diet with thin liquids seen by speech and
   swallow
   Dispo: ICU for HD and chemo today
    Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, currently admitted to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. The patient has a complex medical history, including hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T-max 36.8°C, T-current 36.7°C, HR 96 bpm, BP 113/78 mmHg, RR 26 breaths/min, SpO2 97%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 19 mmHg, HR 96 bpm, BP 113/78 mmHg.
* Fluid balance: Total input 1,561 mL, total output 315 mL, with a balance of 1,246 mL.
* Respiratory support: O2 delivery device nasal cannula, SpO2 97%.
* Laboratory results: WBC 14.8, Hct 29.1, Plt 263 K/uL, Cr 1.0, TCO2 27, Glucose 118, etc.

The patient has several potential medical complications:

1. Renal failure: The patient has a history of acute kidney injury (ARF) and has not shown significant improvement in urine output since ureteral stenting. The patient's creatinine level is normal, but the patient's urine output has been limited.
2. Hypotension and shock: The patient has experienced episodes of hypotension and shock, which may be related to fluid shifts secondary to malignancy or other underlying conditions.
3. Tachycardia: The patient has experienced episodes of tachycardia, which may be related to atrial tachycardia or non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT).
4. Pleural effusions: The patient has a malignant effusion in the left pleural space, which may not resolve promptly.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to her hypotension and other symptoms.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia, which may be contributing to her cardiovascular risk.
7. Aspiration: The patient has a risk of aspiration due to her underlying medical conditions and the presence of a chest tube.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Chemotherapy: The patient will start chemotherapy today with carboplatin 200 mg/m2, with a planned second dose in 21 days.
2. Hemodialysis: The patient will continue to receive hemodialysis, with a plan to start IV albumin for hypotension.
3. Fluid management: The patient will receive IV fluids as needed to manage her hypotension and fluid shifts.
4. Respiratory support: The patient will continue to receive oxygen therapy as needed.
5. Cardiovascular support: The patient will receive IV amiodarone as needed to manage her tachycardia.
6. Nutritional support: The patient will receive nutritional support as needed, with a plan to start IV albumin for hypotension.
7. Endocrine support: The patient will receive thyroid replacement therapy as needed to manage her hypothyroidism.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal care.

   Impression: 74yo woman with presumptive metastatic ovarian cancer and
   persistent hypotension of unclear etiology.

   Anti-emetics and allopurinol per protocol.
   2) Hypotension: Off pressors; etiology remains unclear but there
   appears to be a steroid-responsive component. She has been getting
   Hydrocortisone 50mg IV q6hr.  Will get high dose of decadron for
   chemotherapy so can discontinue hydrocortisone for now.
   3) ID: No e/o systemic infection, however yeast in two recent
   urinalysis. Would repeat UA -- if persistent yeast, would treat with
   fluconazole.
   4) CV: Had been on Amio gtt. No recurrence of tachycardia and was
   likely related to hypotension/HD (situational) rather than primary
   cardiac.  Will discontinue and monitor -> if recurrence then will
   re-evaluate/cards
   5) F/E/N: Continue diet. Follow / replete 'lytes.
   6) Renal: HD today as above.
   7) Hypothyroid: Stable; continue Levoxyl.
   8) Access: RIJ dialysis catheter and PICC line.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with presumptive metastatic ovarian cancer, persistent hypotension, and unclear etiology. She is currently receiving chemotherapy with Carbiplatnum and will undergo hemodialysis (HD) today. Her vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 113/78 mmHg, heart rate of 101 bpm, and respiratory rate of 24 inspirations per minute. She has a history of yeast in her urine and is being treated with antibiotics.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Hypotension:** The patient's hypotension may worsen due to the chemotherapy and HD, which can lead to decreased blood flow to vital organs and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. **Infection:** The presence of yeast in the patient's urine may indicate a systemic infection, which can spread to other parts of the body and cause sepsis.
3. **Fluid overload:** The patient's fluid balance is unstable, with a total fluid input of 1,561 mL and a total fluid output of 315 mL. This may lead to fluid overload and potentially life-threatening complications such as pulmonary edema.
4. **Renal failure:** The patient's kidney function is compromised, as evidenced by her creatinine levels, which may worsen due to the chemotherapy and HD.
5. **Thyroid function:** The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen due to the chemotherapy, which can lead to decreased thyroid hormone production and potentially life-threatening complications such as myxedema coma.
6. **Cardiovascular complications:** The patient's tachycardia may be a sign of cardiac distress, which can worsen due to the chemotherapy and HD.
7. **Nutritional complications:** The patient's nutritional status is compromised, as evidenced by her low albumin levels, which may worsen due to the chemotherapy and HD.
8. **Gastrointestinal complications:** The patient's gastrointestinal function is compromised, as evidenced by her low glucose levels, which may worsen due to the chemotherapy and HD.

**Recommendations:**

1. Monitor the patient's vital signs closely and adjust her fluid management accordingly.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust her HD schedule as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's thyroid function and adjust her thyroid hormone replacement therapy as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust her medication regimen as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust her diet and supplement regimen as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal function and adjust her medication regimen as needed.
7. Consider repeating the patient's urinalysis to monitor for any changes in her urine culture.

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with presumptive metastatic ovarian cancer and persistent hypotension of unclear etiology. She is currently off pressors and is scheduled to receive chemotherapy (Carbiplatnum) today, followed by hemodialysis (HD). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 113/78 mmHg, heart rate of 101 bpm, and respiratory rate of 24 inspirations per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 97% on nasal cannula. She has a history of ovarian cancer, and her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and alkaline phosphatase.

Potential medical complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension may worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased organ perfusion and potential organ damage.
2. Chemo-induced toxicity: The patient is scheduled to receive chemotherapy, which may cause toxicity and side effects, such as nausea, vomiting, and bone marrow suppression.
3. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, and further imbalance may occur due to chemotherapy, HD, or other medical interventions.
4. Infection: The patient has yeast in her urine and may be at risk for developing an infection, particularly if she has a compromised immune system due to her underlying cancer.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of tachyarrhythmias and the use of amiodarone may increase her risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
6. Renal complications: The patient's kidney function is abnormal, and HD may be necessary to manage her kidney function. However, HD may also cause electrolyte imbalance and other complications.
7. Thyroid complications: The patient is taking Levoxyl for hypothyroidism, and her thyroid function should be closely monitored to prevent complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and address potential complications related to her underlying cancer, chemotherapy, and other medical interventions.

   Assessment and Plan
   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia now s/p ureteral stent and one day of chemotherapy.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
    # Renal failure: seems Urine output has not improved significantly
   since stent placement. Cr normal. Patient with episode of hypotension
   that seems to limit ability to do HD. Also seems to have tenous volume
   status.
    - CVVH stopped had first trial of HD with drop in blood pressure, plan
   for HD today 1 hour after initiation of chemotherapy at noon
   - consider IV albumin for hypotension as patient with low oncotic
   pressure
   - s/p stent to ureter to relieve obstruction which did not result in
   increased urinary output
   - urine cx sent intraoperative only growing yeast, urine apparently was
   cloudy, however no evidence of frank pus or abscess, not currently on
   any antibiotics - ordered repeat UA and uculture yesterday, not yet
   sent, will follow-up with results
   # Likely Metastatic ovarian cancer
   - started chemo [**10-1**] day #1 with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of
   1.66. consider second dose 21 days after the first
   - premedication with anti-emeteics including ondansetron, dexamethasone
   on day 1 and 3 days following chemotherapy, dexamethasone OK even in
   addition to IV hydrocortisone as per oncology
   - oncology feels that renal failure and hypotension all related to
   fluid shifts secondary to malignancy and that the only way that she
   will be able to come off of pressors and HD is to treat the cancer
   - still with chest tube in (malignant effusion)
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   # Tachycardia
   -  took multiple EKGs during episode of tachycardia to 130-140s (two
   nights ago). Initial arrythmia looked sinus vs. atrial tachycardia
   which appeared to transition to NSVT, faxed EKGs to cardiology fellow
   overnight, thought was consistent with NSVT, started patient on
   amiodarone IV with adequate reponse, -  during this episode rebolused
   patient with 2x 250 cc fluid for hypotension and tachycardia
   - patient was on IV amiodarone, has not been started on PO amiodarone,
   may hold off for now, and see how patient does (NSVT may have been
   secondary to dialysis in particular rapid electrolyte shifts and fluid
   loss)
   - hold off on cards consults b/c suspect that mostly due to rapid fluid
   shifts, definitely was admiodarone responsive
   - would consider official consult if patient goes back into this rhythm
   again
   # Anemia
   - patient is anemic, ordered anemia work-up labs - iron 27 (low), TIBC
   173 (low), ferritin 222 (high), TRF 133 (low), b12 normal, folate
   normal
   - low iron, low TIBC and elevated ferritin consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease
   #Pleural effusions: Patient still with  output through left tube. Since
   etiology is malignancy may not resolve promptly.
   - likely not candidate for pleuradesis at this time, can follow up with
   thoracics at a later date regarding plan for tube
   - effusions may be contributing to underlying heart physiology
     #. Hypotension and shock.
   - infectious work-up has been negative thus far, blood cultures no
   growth to date, pleural fluid with negative culture, urine cx grew only
   yeast
   - sent repeat UA and culture - repeat UA from [**10-1**] cloudy, large LE,
   large blood, 300 protein, trace ketones, 300 RBCs, 29 WBCs, many
   bacteria, many yeast urine culture pending
   - patient had been off and on pressors now off > 48 hours
   - With continued hypotension two days ago, got IV albumin and also IV
   steroids has has been steroid responsive  previously, again patient
   with good response
   - given that patient to start chemo today , will not taper steroids
   right away, will begin taper tomorrow (tomorrow go to 25 mg IV q
   6hours)
   - elevated white blood cell count in the setting of IV steroids which
   is decreasing as per above do not suspect new infection
    #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - Monitor for a. fib, on thyroid replacement
   - steroids as above
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # Aspiration: on regular diet with thin liquids seen by speech and
   swallow
    Dispo: consider floor transfer today
    Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, initially on pressors and CVVH, who has undergone ureteral stent placement and received her first dose of chemotherapy yesterday. She has been experiencing hypotension, tachycardia, and anemia. Her laboratory results show normal creatinine levels, but her urine output has not improved significantly since stent placement. She has also developed a chest tube for a malignant effusion.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.8°C (98.3°F)
* Heart rate: 98 bpm (normal range)
* Blood pressure: 113/78 mmHg (normal range)
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute (normal range)
* Oxygen saturation: 97% (normal range)
* CVP: -8 mmHg (normal range)

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: No acute distress
* Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2 sounds, no murmur
* Respiratory/Chest: Clear breath sounds on the right side, diminished breath sounds on the left side
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present, distended
* Extremities: 2+ edema in both legs
* Skin: Not assessed
* Neurologic: Attentive, follows simple commands, oriented to person, time, and place

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 14.8 x 10^9/L (normal range)
* Hct: 29.1% (normal range)
* Plt: 68 x 10^9/L (normal range)
* Cr: 1.0 mg/dL (normal range)
* TCO2: 27 mmHg (normal range)
* Glucose: 105 mg/dL (normal range)
* Other labs: See below

The patient's medications include:

* Famotidine (Pepcid) for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Heparin Sodium for prophylaxis
* Lorazepam (Ativan) for sedation
* Other medications: See below

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Renal failure: The patient's urine output has not improved significantly since stent placement, and her creatinine levels are normal. This may indicate that the patient's kidneys are functioning normally, but further monitoring is needed to ensure that the patient's kidney function does not deteriorate.
2. Hypotension and shock: The patient has been experiencing hypotension and shock, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly. The patient's blood pressure should be closely monitored, and fluids should be administered as needed to maintain blood pressure.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be caused by chronic disease, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause of the anemia.
4. Malignant effusion: The patient has a malignant effusion, which can cause respiratory distress and other complications. The patient's chest tube should be monitored closely to ensure that the effusion is not worsening.
5. Infection: The patient's urine culture has grown yeast, and further evaluation is needed to determine if the patient has an infection.
6. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be caused by rapid fluid shifts, electrolyte imbalances, or other factors. The patient's heart rate should be closely monitored, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause of the tachycardia.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which can cause a range of symptoms including fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. The patient's thyroid function should be closely monitored, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause of the hypothyroidism.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination findings closely to ensure that the patient's condition does not deteriorate.
2. Administer fluids as needed to maintain blood pressure and prevent hypotension and shock.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's urine output and creatinine levels to ensure that the patient's kidneys are functioning normally.
4. Consider consulting with a nephrologist to further evaluate the patient's kidney function and develop a plan for managing the patient's kidney function.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's chest tube and effusion to ensure that the effusion is not worsening.
6. Consider consulting with an infectious disease specialist to further evaluate the patient's urine culture and determine if the patient has an infection.

8. Continue to monitor the patient's hypothyroidism and consider consulting with an endocrinologist to further evaluate the patient's thyroid function and develop a plan for managing the patient's hypothyroidism.

Based on the patient's condition, I also recommend the following:

1. Continue to administer chemotherapy as planned, with close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's white blood cell count and platelet count to ensure that the patient's bone marrow is functioning normally.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust the patient's medication regimen as needed to ensure that the patient's electrolyte levels remain within normal ranges.

5. Continue to monitor the patient's oxygen saturation and adjust the patient's oxygen therapy as needed to ensure that the patient's oxygen saturation remains within normal ranges.

Based on the patient's condition, I believe that the patient is at risk for developing further complications, including renal failure, hypotension and shock, anemia, malignant effusion, infection, tachycardia, and hypothyroidism.    Assessment and Plan
   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia now s/p ureteral stent and one day of chemotherapy.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
    # Renal failure: seems Urine output has not improved significantly
   since stent placement. Cr normal. Patient with episode of hypotension
   that seems to limit ability to do HD. Also seems to have tenous volume
   status.
    - CVVH stopped had first trial of HD with drop in blood pressure, got
   HD yesterday without large swings in her blood pressure, plan is to
   likely get HD today
   - s/p stent to ureter to relieve obstruction which did not result in
   increased urinary output
   - urine cx sent intraoperative only growing [**Month/Day (2) 1564**], urine apparently was
   cloudy, however no evidence of frank pus or abscess, not currently on
   any antibiotics - ordered repeat culture yesterday
   - given two positive urines with [**Last Name (LF) 1564**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] go ahead at this time and
   treat at this time with fluconazole for 7 day course
   # Likely Metastatic ovarian cancer
   - started chemo [**10-1**] day #1 with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of
   1.66. consider second dose 21 days after the first
   - premedication with anti-emeteics including ondansetron, dexamethasone
   on day 1 and 3 days following chemotherapy, dexamethasone OK even in
   addition to IV hydrocortisone as per oncology
   - oncology feels that renal failure and hypotension all related to
   fluid shifts secondary to malignancy and that the only way that she
   will be able to come off of pressors and HD is to treat the cancer
   - still with chest tube in (malignant effusion) with decent output
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   # Tachycardia
   - patient again tachycardic this morning possible etiologies include
   sinus tachycardia secondary to volume loss from HD, or new infection
   - will check a chest x-ray, start on fluconazole for [**Month/Year (2) 1564**] in the urine
   x 7 days
   - continue to follow
   -  previous episode of tachycardia s/p first HD - took multiple EKGs
   during episode of tachycardia to 130-140s (two nights ago). Initial
   arrythmia looked sinus vs. atrial tachycardia which appeared to
   transition to NSVT, faxed EKGs to cardiology fellow, thought was
   consistent with NSVT, started patient on amiodarone IV with adequate
   reponse, -  during this episode rebolused patient with 2x 250 cc fluid
   for hypotension and tachycardia
   - patient was on IV amiodarone, has not been started on PO amiodarone,
   will hold off for now, and see how patient does (NSVT may have been
   secondary to dialysis in particular rapid electrolyte shifts and fluid
   loss)
   - hold off on cards consults b/c suspect that mostly due to rapid fluid
   shifts, definitely was admiodarone responsive\
   # Anemia
   - patient is anemic, ordered anemia work-up labs - iron 27 (low), TIBC
   173 (low), ferritin 222 (high), TRF 133 (low), b12 normal, folate
   normal
   - low iron, low TIBC and elevated ferritin consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease
   #Pleural effusions: Patient still with  significant output through left
   tube. Since etiology is malignancy may not resolve promptly.
   - likely not candidate for pleuradesis at this time, can follow up with
   thoracics at a later date regarding plan for tube
   - wiill need to address plans for chest tube on discharge
   - effusions may be contributing to underlying heart physiology
     #. Hypotension and shock.
   - infectious work-up has been negative thus far, blood cultures no
   growth to date, pleural fluid with negative culture, urine cx grew only
   [**Month/Year (2) 1564**], given lack of other source  will start treatment [**10-2**]
   - sent repeat UA and culture - repeat UA from [**10-1**] cloudy, large LE,
   large blood, 300 protein, trace ketones, 300 RBCs, 29 WBCs, many
   bacteria, many [**Month/Year (2) 1564**] urine culture pending
   - patient currently off pressors with good blood pressure, still on IV
   steroids
   - previously  got IV albumin and also IV steroids for hypotension with
   good response
   - will start steroid taper today  (tomorrow go to 25 mg IV q 6hours)
    #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - Monitor for a. fib, on thyroid replacement
   - steroids as above
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # Aspiration: on regular diet with thin liquids seen by speech and
   swallow
    Dispo: consider transfer to floor tomorrow or later this afternoon if
   stabilizes
    Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, who was admitted to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. She has a history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia. The patient was initially on pressors and CVVH, but was later switched to hemodialysis (HD) with a good response. She received her first dose of chemotherapy yesterday and is currently on a 7-day course of fluconazole for a urinary tract infection.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, blood pressure of 113/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97% on nasal cannula. Her respiratory support includes a chest tube for a malignant effusion, which is producing a significant amount of fluid.

The patient's laboratory results show normal renal function, with a creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL. Her anemia work-up reveals low iron, low TIBC, and elevated ferritin, consistent with anemia of chronic disease. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Renal failure: The patient's urine output has not improved significantly since stent placement, and her creatinine level is normal. This may indicate that her kidney function is compromised, which could lead to further complications.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been labile, and she has required frequent rebolusing with fluids. This could lead to further hypotension and shock.
3. Infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection, which could spread to other parts of the body and cause further complications.
4. Malignant effusion: The patient has a significant amount of fluid in her chest cavity, which could lead to respiratory compromise and further complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia work-up reveals low iron, low TIBC, and elevated ferritin, which could lead to further complications if not addressed.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism could be contributing to her hypotension and other symptoms, and may require further management.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia could increase her risk of cardiovascular complications, and may require further management.

Overall, the patient is at risk for several medical complications, including renal failure, hypotension, infection, malignant effusion, anemia, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia. It is essential to monitor her closely and address any complications that arise promptly to ensure her optimal care and outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's condition appears to be stable, with some improvements noted. The patient tolerated hemodialysis (HD) without complications and has decreased edema. However, there are several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 97/42 mmHg, which is low. The note mentions that this may be related to a steroid-responsive component, and the patient's blood pressure should be closely monitored.
2. Tachyapnea: The patient's respiratory rate is 32 breaths per minute, which is slightly elevated. A chest X-ray (CXR) should be checked to rule out any underlying pulmonary pathology.
3. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 9.1 g/dL, which is low. The patient may require blood transfusions to correct this.
4. UTI: The patient has a persistent yeast infection, and treatment with Diflucan has been initiated.
5. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisol levels should be monitored to rule out adrenal insufficiency.
6. Respiratory support: The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via a nasal cannula, and their SpO2 level is 97%. However, their ABG results show a pH of 7.29, which may indicate respiratory acidosis.
7. Fluid balance: The patient has a negative fluid balance of 1,426 mL, which may indicate dehydration.
8. Cardiac status: The patient's heart rhythm is sinus tachycardia, with a heart rate of 103 beats per minute. Their blood pressure is low, which may indicate cardiac compromise.
9. Neurological status: The patient's neurological examination is incomplete, and their responsiveness, movement, and tone are not assessed.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is stable, but there are several potential medical complications that can arise. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and medical condition is necessary to prevent and manage these complications.

The patient has a chest tube that is still draining significant amounts of fluid and will not be removed at this time. The patient has anemia and is receiving dialysis. The patient also has a UTI and is being treated with Diflucan. The patient has adrenal insufficiency and is being monitored.

The patient has a PICC line, arterial line, and dialysis catheter in place. The patient is receiving prophylactic treatment for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Further deterioration of the patient's respiratory status due to tachypnea and potential respiratory failure.

5. Development of respiratory failure due to pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
6. Development of cardiovascular complications such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
7. Development of neurologic complications such as seizures or stroke.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, lab results, and clinical status closely to identify any potential complications early and initiate appropriate interventions.

   Assessment and Plan
   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia now s/p ureteral stent and one day of chemotherapy.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   # Tachycardia
   - patient continues to have episodes of tachycardia overnight, despite
   not having any fluid taken off yesterday (no HD). This could be sinus
   tachycardia secondary to 3^rd spacing, causing patient to be IV dry
   (although not hypotensive), new infection (?PNA on CXR or yeast in
   urine), or paraneoplastic event given her malignancy.
   -started on fluconazole for yeast infection (day 2 today)
   -  previous episode of tachycardia s/p first HD - took multiple EKGs
   during episode of tachycardia to 130-140s (two nights ago). Initial
   arrythmia looked sinus vs. atrial tachycardia which appeared to
   transition to NSVT, faxed EKGs to cardiology fellow, thought was
   consistent with NSVT, started patient on amiodarone IV with adequate
   reponse, -  during this episode rebolused patient with 2x 250 cc fluid
   for hypotension and tachycardia
   - patient was on IV amiodarone, has not been started on PO amiodarone,
   will hold off for now, and see how patient does (NSVT may have been
   secondary to dialysis in particular rapid electrolyte shifts and fluid
   loss)
   - hold off on cards consults b/c suspect that mostly due to rapid fluid
   shifts, amiodarone responsive
    # Renal failure: seems Urine output has not improved significantly
   since stent placement. Cr normal. Patient with episode of hypotension
   that seems to limit ability to do HD. Also seems to have tenous volume
   status.
    - CVVH stopped had first trial of HD with drop in blood pressure,
   possible HD today
   - s/p stent to ureter to relieve obstruction which did not result in
   increased urinary output
   - urine cx sent intraoperative only growing yeast, urine apparently was
   cloudy, however no evidence of frank pus or abscess, not currently on
   any antibiotics
 currently on fluconazole for 7 days
   # Malignancy-? Metastatic ovarian cancer
   - started chemo [**10-1**] day #1 with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of
   1.66. consider second dose 21 days after the first
   - premedication with anti-emeteics including ondansetron, dexamethasone
   on day 1 and 3 days following chemotherapy, dexamethasone OK even in
   addition to IV hydrocortisone as per oncology
   - oncology feels that renal failure and hypotension all related to
   fluid shifts secondary to malignancy and that the only way that she
   will be able to come off of pressors and HD is to treat the cancer
   - still with chest tube in (malignant effusion) with decent output
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome- follow tumor lysis labs
   # Anemia of chronic disease
   - patient is anemic, ordered anemia work-up labs - iron 27 (low), TIBC
   173 (low), ferritin 222 (high), TRF 133 (low), b12 normal, folate
   normal
   - low iron, low TIBC and elevated ferritin consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease
   #Pleural effusions: patient
s chest tube fell out yesterday during
   transport. IP and thoracic surgery aware, and will replace today. CXR
   showed no PTX. Currently sterile dressing in place.Patient still with
   significant output through left tube.
   -contact thoracic surgery for Chest tube replacement today
   - likely not candidate for pleuradesis at this time
   -also given tachycardia, tachypnea and hazy CXR started vanco, zosyn
   yesterday for concern of HAP.
     #. Hypotension and shock.
   - infectious work-up has been negative thus far, blood cultures no
   growth to date, pleural fluid with negative culture, urine cx grew
   yeast, given lack of other source  started fluconazole treatment [**10-2**]
   -CXR with ?PNA started vanco, zosyn for suspected HAP
   - patient currently off pressors with good blood pressure, still on IV
   steroids
   - previously  got IV albumin and also IV steroids for hypotension with
   good response
   - will start steroid taper today  at 25 mg IV q 6hours
    #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - Monitor for a. fib, on thyroid replacement
   - steroids as above
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # Aspiration: on regular diet with thin liquids seen by speech and
   swallow
    Dispo: consider transfer to floor tomorrow or later this afternoon if
   stabilizes
    Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, who is currently in the ICU due to ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. The patient has a complex medical history, including hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, and a history of hypertension.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is experiencing tachypnea, with a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute. The CXR shows possible infiltrates and opacities.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has ongoing episodes of tachycardia, despite being on pressors. The patient's blood pressure is stable, but the patient is experiencing hypotension. The patient has a history of hypotension and shock.
* Renal: The patient has ongoing renal failure, with a urine output that has not improved significantly since stent placement. The patient's creatinine levels are normal.
* Infectious: The patient has a yeast infection in the urine, and is currently being treated with fluconazole. The patient's blood cultures have been negative to date.
* Malignancy: The patient has metastatic ovarian cancer, and is currently receiving chemotherapy.
* Anemia: The patient is anemic, with a low iron level and elevated ferritin level, consistent with anemia of chronic disease.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Pneumonia: The patient's CXR shows possible infiltrates and opacities, which could be indicative of pneumonia.
* Sepsis: The patient's ongoing episodes of tachycardia and hypotension could be indicative of sepsis.
* Renal failure: The patient's ongoing renal failure could lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
* Malignancy progression: The patient's metastatic ovarian cancer could continue to progress, leading to further complications and potentially life-threatening outcomes.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia could lead to further complications, such as fatigue, weakness, and decreased immune function.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan should be considered:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status, and consider further imaging studies to rule out pneumonia.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status, and consider further interventions to manage the patient's tachycardia and hypotension.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal status, and consider further interventions to manage the patient's ongoing renal failure.
* Continue to monitor the patient's infectious status, and consider further interventions to manage the patient's yeast infection.
* Continue to monitor the patient's malignancy status, and consider further interventions to manage the patient's metastatic ovarian cancer.
* Consider further interventions to manage the patient's anemia, such as blood transfusions or iron supplementation.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic ovarian cancer, newly diagnosed and treated with chemotherapy. She was transferred to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. She has a history of hypothyroidism, HLD, and ARF. She presented to the ED with ARF and hyperkalemia, and has since developed tachycardia, tachypnea, and hazy CXR consistent with possible pneumonia. She has a chest tube in place for left pleural effusion, which fell out overnight. She is currently on pressors and has been started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for suspected HAP.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia (HAP): The patient's tachypnea, tachycardia, and hazy CXR suggest the possibility of pneumonia, which could lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, and multi-organ dysfunction.
2. Left Pleural Effusion: The patient's chest tube fell out overnight, which may lead to re-accumulation of fluid and potential respiratory compromise.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's BUN and Cr levels are elevated, indicating acute renal failure, which could lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and fluid overload.
4. Ovarian Cancer: The patient's underlying malignancy could lead to further complications, such as metastases, bleeding, or organ dysfunction.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism could lead to persistent hypotension, bradycardia, and other systemic complications.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia could increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as MI, stroke, or atherosclerosis.
7. Anemia of Chronic Disease: The patient's anemia could lead to fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
8. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid overload could lead to respiratory distress, cardiac failure, and electrolyte imbalances.
9. Sepsis: The patient's suspected HAP could lead to sepsis, which could cause multi-organ dysfunction and high mortality.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan should focus on addressing the above potential complications. The plan should include:

* Continuing antibiotics for suspected HAP
* Initiating hemodialysis to manage acute renal failure
* Evaluating and replacing the chest tube for left pleural effusion
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and adjusting therapy accordingly
* Managing hypothyroidism with thyroid replacement therapy
* Monitoring for signs of hyperlipidemia and adjusting therapy accordingly
* Managing anemia of chronic disease with iron and folate supplementation
* Monitoring for signs of fluid overload and adjusting therapy accordingly
* Considering transfer to a floor or other facility after hemodialysis and chest tube replacement.

   Assessment and Plan
   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia now s/p ureteral stent and one day of chemotherapy.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
    # Renal failure: seems Urine output has not improved significantly
   since stent placement. Cr normal. Patient with episode of hypotension
   that seems to limit ability to do HD. Also seems to have tenous volume
   status.
    - CVVH stopped had first trial of HD with drop in blood pressure, got
   HD yesterday without large swings in her blood pressure, plan is to
   likely get HD today
   - s/p stent to ureter to relieve obstruction which did not result in
   increased urinary output
   - urine cx sent intraoperative only growing [**Month/Day (2) 1564**], urine apparently was
   cloudy, however no evidence of frank pus or abscess, not currently on
   any antibiotics - ordered repeat culture yesterday
   - given two positive urines with [**Last Name (LF) 1564**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] go ahead at this time and
   treat at this time with fluconazole for 7 day course
   # Likely Metastatic ovarian cancer
   - started chemo [**10-1**] day #1 with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of
   1.66. consider second dose 21 days after the first
   - premedication with anti-emeteics including ondansetron, dexamethasone
   on day 1 and 3 days following chemotherapy, dexamethasone OK even in
   addition to IV hydrocortisone as per oncology
   - oncology feels that renal failure and hypotension all related to
   fluid shifts secondary to malignancy and that the only way that she
   will be able to come off of pressors and HD is to treat the cancer
   - still with chest tube in (malignant effusion) with decent output
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   # Tachycardia
   - patient again tachycardic this morning possible etiologies include
   sinus tachycardia secondary to volume loss from HD, or new infection
   - will check a chest x-ray, start on fluconazole for [**Month/Year (2) 1564**] in the urine
   x 7 days
   - continue to follow
   -  previous episode of tachycardia s/p first HD - took multiple EKGs
   during episode of tachycardia to 130-140s (two nights ago). Initial
   arrythmia looked sinus vs. atrial tachycardia which appeared to
   transition to NSVT, faxed EKGs to cardiology fellow, thought was
   consistent with NSVT, started patient on amiodarone IV with adequate
   reponse, -  during this episode rebolused patient with 2x 250 cc fluid
   for hypotension and tachycardia
   - patient was on IV amiodarone, has not been started on PO amiodarone,
   will hold off for now, and see how patient does (NSVT may have been
   secondary to dialysis in particular rapid electrolyte shifts and fluid
   loss)
   - hold off on cards consults b/c suspect that mostly due to rapid fluid
   shifts, definitely was admiodarone responsive\
   # Anemia
   - patient is anemic, ordered anemia work-up labs - iron 27 (low), TIBC
   173 (low), ferritin 222 (high), TRF 133 (low), b12 normal, folate
   normal
   - low iron, low TIBC and elevated ferritin consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease
   #Pleural effusions: Patient still with  significant output through left
   tube. Since etiology is malignancy may not resolve promptly.
   - likely not candidate for pleuradesis at this time, can follow up with
   thoracics at a later date regarding plan for tube
   - wiill need to address plans for chest tube on discharge
   - effusions may be contributing to underlying heart physiology
     #. Hypotension and shock.
   - infectious work-up has been negative thus far, blood cultures no
   growth to date, pleural fluid with negative culture, urine cx grew only
   [**Month/Year (2) 1564**], given lack of other source  will start treatment [**10-2**]
   - sent repeat UA and culture - repeat UA from [**10-1**] cloudy, large LE,
   large blood, 300 protein, trace ketones, 300 RBCs, 29 WBCs, many
   bacteria, many [**Month/Year (2) 1564**] urine culture pending
   - patient currently off pressors with good blood pressure, still on IV
   steroids
   - previously  got IV albumin and also IV steroids for hypotension with
   good response
   - will start steroid taper today  (tomorrow go to 25 mg IV q 6hours)
    #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - Monitor for a. fib, on thyroid replacement
   - steroids as above
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # Aspiration: on regular diet with thin liquids seen by speech and
   swallow
    Dispo: consider transfer to floor tomorrow or later this afternoon if
   stabilizes
    Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer, who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department (ED) due to acute renal failure (ARF) and hyperkalemia. She was initially treated with ureteral stenting and chemotherapy.

Current issues:

1. Renal failure: The patient's urine output has not improved significantly since the ureteral stent placement, and her creatinine levels are normal. CVVH was stopped due to hypotension, and HD was attempted yesterday without significant blood pressure fluctuations. The plan is to continue HD today.
2. Tachycardia: The patient is tachycardic, with a possible etiology of sinus tachycardia secondary to volume loss from HD or new infection. A chest X-ray was ordered, and fluconazole was started for [**Month/Year (2) 1564**] in the urine for 7 days.
3. Anemia: The patient is anemic, with low iron, low TIBC, and elevated ferritin levels consistent with anemia of chronic disease.
4. Pleural effusions: The patient has significant output through her left chest tube, which is likely due to malignancy and may not resolve promptly.
5. Hypotension and shock: The patient has had negative infectious work-up results, and her blood cultures have not grown any bacteria. She was started on treatment [**10-2**] due to lack of other source.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to her persistent hypotension.

Potential medical complications:

1. Fluid overload: The patient is at risk of fluid overload due to her ongoing HD and IV fluids.
2. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's rapid fluid shifts and electrolyte losses may lead to electrolyte imbalances.
3. Infection: The patient is at risk of infection due to her immunocompromised state and ongoing invasive procedures.
4. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and ongoing HD may increase her risk of bleeding.
5. Cardiac issues: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may be related to cardiac issues, which need to be monitored closely.
6. Malignancy progression: The patient's metastatic ovarian cancer may continue to progress, leading to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue HD and monitor the patient's fluid status and electrolyte levels closely.
2. Monitor the patient's tachycardia and consider adjusting her treatment plan if necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusions if necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's pleural effusions and plan for chest tube removal when necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's hypotension and shock, and consider adjusting her treatment plan if necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hypothyroidism and adjust her thyroid replacement therapy as necessary.
7. Consider consulting with cardiology and endocrinology to further evaluate the patient's cardiac and endocrine status.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-inch, 105.4 kg individual admitted to the ICU with a history of chest tube removal, tachypnea, tachycardia, and infiltrates on a chest X-ray. They have been receiving vancomycin and zosyn for suspected sepsis. The patient has a history of oxycodone allergy and nausea/vomiting.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C (98.5°F), heart rate of 107 bpm, blood pressure of 95/58 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute. The patient is receiving oxygen via nasal cannula and has a SpO2 of 99%.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate levels, and troponin-T, indicating potential cardiac and septic complications. The patient's kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 26 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count, lactate levels, and troponin-T suggest the possibility of sepsis. Close monitoring of vital signs and lab results is necessary to detect early signs of sepsis.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's impaired kidney function, as indicated by elevated creatinine and BUN levels, may worsen if not managed promptly.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponin-T level and sinus tachycardia may indicate cardiac damage or stress.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and infiltrates on chest X-ray may indicate respiratory failure, which could worsen if not managed promptly.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's impaired nutritional status, as indicated by elevated lactate levels and decreased albumin levels, may worsen if not addressed promptly.
6. Bloodstream infections: The patient's central lines and arterial line increase the risk of bloodstream infections, which could be life-threatening if not managed promptly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and lab results closely for signs of sepsis or other complications.
2. Initiate early and aggressive treatment for suspected sepsis, including broad-spectrum antibiotics and vasopressors as needed.
3. Manage the patient's kidney function with fluid and electrolyte management, as well as consideration of dialysis if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac function closely and consider echocardiography or other imaging studies to evaluate cardiac damage.
5. Implement respiratory support measures, such as non-invasive ventilation or mechanical ventilation, if necessary.
6. Address the patient's nutritional deficiencies with enteral or parenteral nutrition, as needed.
7. Consider removing the patient's central lines and arterial line if not necessary, to reduce the risk of bloodstream infections.

   Assessment and Plan
   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia now s/p ureteral stent and one day of chemotherapy.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   # Tachycardia
   - patient continues to have episodes of tachycardia overnight, despite
   not having any fluid taken off yesterday (no HD). This could be sinus
   tachycardia secondary to 3^rd spacing, causing patient to be IV dry
   (although not hypotensive), new infection (?PNA on CXR or yeast in
   urine), or paraneoplastic event given her malignancy.
   -started on fluconazole for yeast infection (day 2 today)
   - patient was on IV amiodarone, has not been started on PO amiodarone,
   will hold off for now, and monitor telemetry
   - if persists or becomes HD unstable will consult cardiology and
   consider starting low dose beta blocker
   - repeat EKG post HD
    # Renal failure: HD today
   -d/c foley as colonized
   - monitor electrolytes and replete prn
   -f/u renal recs
   # Malignancy-? Metastatic ovarian cancer- started chemo [**10-1**] day #1
   with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of 1.66. consider second dose 21
   days after the first. oncology feels that renal failure and hypotension
   all related to fluid shifts secondary to malignancy and that the only
   way that she will be able to come off of pressors and HD is to treat
   the cancer
   - will need to replace chest tube today, IP to come see patient
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome- follow tumor lysis labs
   # Anemia of chronic disease
   - patient is anemic, ordered anemia work-up labs - iron 27 (low), TIBC
   173 (low), ferritin 222 (high), TRF 133 (low), b12 normal, folate
   normal
   - low iron, low TIBC and elevated ferritin consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease
   #Pleural effusions: patient
s chest tube fell out yesterday during
   transport. IP and thoracic surgery aware, and will replace today. CXR
   showed no PTX. Currently sterile dressing in place.Patient still with
   significant output through left tube.
   -contact thoracic surgery for Chest tube replacement today
   -also given tachycardia, tachypnea and hazy CXR started vanco, zosyn
   yesterday for concern of HAP
   -consider sending sputum culture
     #. Hypotension and shock.
   -CXR with ?PNA started vanco, zosyn for suspected HAP
   - patient currently off pressors with good blood pressure, still on IV
   steroids
   - previously  got IV albumin and also IV steroids for hypotension with
   good response
   - will start steroid taper post dialysis  at 25 mg IV q 6hours
    #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - Monitor for a. fib, on thyroid replacement
   - steroids as above
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # Aspiration: on regular diet with thin liquids seen by speech and
   swallow
    Dispo: consider transfer to floor later this afternoon post HD and IP

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic ovarian cancer who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department due to acute kidney injury (ARF) and hyperkalemia. She underwent ureteral stenting and received one day of chemotherapy.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Tachycardia, which may be secondary to sinus tachycardia, new infection, or paraneoplastic event
* Renal failure, treated with hemodialysis (HD) today
* Hypotension, which may be related to fluid shifts secondary to malignancy
* Anemia of chronic disease, with low iron, low TIBC, and elevated ferritin
* Pleural effusions, with a chest tube that fell out yesterday and needs to be replaced today
* Hazy CXR, with suspected HAP, and started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam
* Hypothyroidism, with a consultation with endocrinology to help elucidate the cause of persistent hypotension
* Hyperlipidemia, with a recommendation to continue home statin dose

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac complications due to tachycardia and hypotension, such as arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, or heart failure
* Respiratory complications due to HAP, such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or respiratory failure
* Renal complications due to ongoing renal failure, such as electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, or chronic kidney disease
* Infection complications due to the presence of a chest tube and potential bacterial colonization
* Malignancy complications due to the patient's metastatic ovarian cancer, such as tumor lysis syndrome, hypercalcemia, or hyperkalemia
* Hematological complications due to anemia of chronic disease, such as bleeding, thrombocytopenia, or leukopenia

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia now s/p ureteral stent and one day of chemotherapy.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   # Tachycardia
   - patient continues to have episodes of tachycardia overnight, despite
   not having any fluid taken off yesterday (no HD). This could be sinus
   tachycardia secondary to 3^rd spacing, causing patient to be IV dry
   (although not hypotensive), new infection (?PNA on CXR or yeast in
   urine), or paraneoplastic event given her malignancy.
   -started on fluconazole for yeast infection (day 2 today)
   - patient was on IV amiodarone, has not been started on PO amiodarone,
   will hold off for now, and monitor telemetry
   - if persists or becomes HD unstable will consult cardiology and
   consider starting low dose beta blocker
   - repeat EKG post HD
    # Renal failure: HD today
   -d/c foley as colonized
   - monitor electrolytes and replete prn
   -f/u renal recs
   # Malignancy-? Metastatic ovarian cancer- started chemo [**10-1**] day #1
   with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of 1.66. consider second dose 21
   days after the first. oncology feels that renal failure and hypotension
   all related to fluid shifts secondary to malignancy and that the only
   way that she will be able to come off of pressors and HD is to treat
   the cancer
   - will need to replace chest tube today, IP to come see patient
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome- follow tumor lysis labs
   # Anemia of chronic disease
   - patient is anemic, ordered anemia work-up labs - iron 27 (low), TIBC
   173 (low), ferritin 222 (high), TRF 133 (low), b12 normal, folate
   normal
   - low iron, low TIBC and elevated ferritin consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease
   #Pleural effusions: patient
s chest tube fell out yesterday during
   transport. IP and thoracic surgery aware, and will replace today. CXR
   showed no PTX. Currently sterile dressing in place.Patient still with
   significant output through left tube.
   -contact thoracic surgery for Chest tube replacement today
   -also given tachycardia, tachypnea and hazy CXR started vanco, zosyn
   yesterday for concern of HAP
   -consider sending sputum culture
     #. Hypotension and shock.
   -CXR with ?PNA started vanco, zosyn for suspected HAP
   - patient currently off pressors with good blood pressure, still on IV
   steroids
   - previously  got IV albumin and also IV steroids for hypotension with
   good response
   - will start steroid taper post dialysis  at 25 mg IV q 6hours
    #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - Monitor for a. fib, on thyroid replacement
   - steroids as above
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # Aspiration: on regular diet with thin liquids seen by speech and
   swallow
    Dispo: consider transfer to floor later this afternoon post HD and IP
   consult for line
    Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be secondary to sinus tachycardia, new infection, or paraneoplastic event. The patient is being monitored for tachycardia and may require further evaluation and treatment.
2. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further fluid shifts and electrolyte imbalances.
3. Malignancy: The patient's metastatic ovarian cancer may progress and cause further complications, such as respiratory distress, sepsis, and bleeding.
4. Anemia of chronic disease: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
5. Pleural effusions: The patient's pleural effusions may worsen if not properly managed, leading to respiratory distress, pleuritic pain, and decreased lung function.
6. Hypotension and shock: The patient's hypotension and shock may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further organ dysfunction and decreased perfusion of vital organs.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further fatigue, weakness, and decreased metabolic rate.
8. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further cardiovascular risk and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
9. Aspiration: The patient's aspiration risk may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further respiratory complications and decreased lung function.
10. Infection: The patient's risk of infection may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further sepsis, organ dysfunction, and decreased survival.

The patient's care plan includes:

* Managing tachycardia with further evaluation and treatment as necessary
* Managing renal failure with dialysis and electrolyte repletion
* Managing malignancy with chemotherapy and palliative care
* Managing anemia of chronic disease with iron supplementation and erythropoietin
* Managing pleural effusions with chest tube replacement and drainage
* Managing hypotension and shock with fluid resuscitation and vasopressor support
* Managing hypothyroidism with thyroid replacement and monitoring
* Managing hyperlipidemia with statin therapy and lifestyle modifications
* Managing aspiration risk with speech and swallow therapy and diet modification
* Managing infection risk with antibiotic therapy and infection control measures.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient, a 74-year-old female, was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department (ED) due to acute renal failure (ARF) and hyperkalemia. She was diagnosed with metastatic ovarian cancer and underwent ureteral stenting and chemotherapy. The patient is currently receiving pressors and hemodialysis (HD) due to hypotension and renal failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 103 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/62 mmHg. She is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and has a SpO2 of 96%. The patient's respiratory support includes a non-invasive ventilation device.

The patient's physical examination reveals anasarca (edema) in the sacrum, legs, and arms. Her neurological examination is normal, with no signs of altered mental status or focal neurological deficits.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a white blood cell count of 14.8 K/uL. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of hypocalcemia (Ca++: 8.4 mg/dL). Her liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 55 IU/L and an alkaline phosphatase level of 24 IU/L.

The patient's medical conditions include hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, and anemia of chronic disease. She is receiving treatment for pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and pleural effusions.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's tachycardia and non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) episodes may indicate a risk of cardiac arrhythmias, which can be life-threatening.
2. Renal failure: The patient's ongoing renal failure may require further interventions, such as continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) or peritoneal dialysis.
3. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and urinary tract infection may require antibiotic adjustments or additional antimicrobial therapy.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may require further evaluation and treatment, including iron supplementation or blood transfusions.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may require thyroid replacement therapy to manage her symptoms and prevent complications.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may require lifestyle modifications or medication to manage her cholesterol levels.
7. Pleural effusions: The patient's pleural effusions may require drainage or thoracocentesis to manage her symptoms and prevent complications.
8. Malignancy: The patient's metastatic ovarian cancer may require further chemotherapy or other treatments to manage her disease and prevent complications.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend close monitoring of her vital signs, laboratory results, and medical conditions. Additionally, I suggest consulting with cardiology, oncology, and other specialists as needed to manage the patient's complex medical conditions.
